GREENWOOD LAKE, N.J., June 5. Preparations are complete and everything is in readiness for the single-scull race for $1,000 to be rowed here tomorrow between George Lee, of Newark, and John Kennedy, of Portland, Me. CHAMBERSBURG Penn., June 5. The execution of Peter Swingler, colored, for the murder of John Anderson, also colored, on Dec. 17 last, at Wolffstown, a suburb of this place, took place here to-day. The sentence against Alexander Solovieff, who attempted the assassination of the Emperor of Russia, on the 14th of last April, and was convicted, on the 6th inst., before the Supreme Tribunal, of belonging to an association for the overthrow of the State, was carried out to-day. WASHINGTON, June 9.--At a meeting of the National Board of Health on Saturday regulations were adopted in regard to maritime quarantine, providing for attention to cleanliness on the part of masters of ships sailing from any foreign port liable to contagious disease, and care in excluding from their ships passengers or goods suspected, of being infected.

BERLIN, June 9.--The Duke of Edinburgh will arrive here on Tuesday to represent British royalty on the occasion of the imperial fete. The Empress and Prince Bismarck have returned to this city.

Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill relating to vinegar factories established and operated prior to March 1, 1879. A determined effort is being made to secure the pardon of Frank Cosgrove, the son of a Burlingslip broker, indicted for being a participant in the now notorious Cora Sammis malpractice case. FALL RIVER, Mass., June 25.--The great struggle between the manufacturers and spinners begins to-morrow. The ground has been all looked over and the plans all laid. The contest promises to be a sharp one. How long it will last is uncertain, but the generally accepted opinion is that the manufacturers will win, though the spinners affirm that they will make it a costly victory.

At the Richmond County Court-house yesterday, before Judge Westervelt, the trials were begun of the several officers of Staten Island, who have been charged with malfeasance in office and other crimes. Thomas L. Sandford owned property in Madison-avenue, near Sixty-third-street, and a Mr. Rowe had a mortgage upon it. NORTH ADAMS, Mass., June 30. For the fifth time in nine years North Adams is thrown into a fever of excitement by the blowing up of Prof. George M. Mowbray's glycerine works. It was known at once that an accident had occurred.

BISMARCK, Dakota, July 1. An electricstorm, as the Signal Officer calls it, broke upon this city and its vicinity about 7:30 o'clock last evening. LEBANON, Penn., July 3. Meinrod Spattenhuber, who was convicted, at the last January term, of the murder of John Ivison, was hanged in the jail-yard of this borough today. CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 3. On Wednesday night the usually quiet village of Canandaigua, Ontario County, was the scene of a double tragedy of the most shocking character. Jacob Neu, a thrifty German gardener, was the principal actor and his wife Barbara the victim.

Jeromiah Murphy, the Young boatman who was shot in the head at Verplanck's Point by James Nolan last Wednesday night, is still living, but Dr. Lyon, of Peekskill, who has closely attended him since he was wounded, has no hope of his recovery.
Adjt-Gen. Steele, of Texas, reports that there are between 4,000 and 5,000 fugitives from justice from that State, of whom 851 are murderers.

NEWBURG, N.Y., JulY 8. The work of digging on the land of Hugh Kelly, at Little Britain, for the bones lacking to make the skeleton of the mastodon complete was continued yesterday, and, as a result, three more ribs and the first joint of the imperfect hind leg were unearthed.

LONDON, July 8. The Prince and Princess of Wales, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, and the Duke and Duchess of Connaught attended the fete and fancy fair at the Royal Albert Hall yesterday, for the benefit of the French Hospital and other benevolent institutions in London. It is estimated that 6,000 has already been realized.

Scenes in the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, suggest reminiscences of old times. Charges of bribery and corruption were made, and the City Fathers requested an inquisitive public to look them is the eye.

Unfortunately, the persistent inclemency of a season without a parallel in recent times entirely frustrated the ceremony.

CINCINNATI, July 9. Col. Thomas Buford, the Kentuckian who slew Judge Elliott, of the Court of Appeals, for rendering an adverse decision in a case in which the Buford family was interested, was removed from Louisville Jail to-day to Owenton, and his trial for murder was formally begun.

Mrs. William A. Mathews, who lived at No. 141 East Thirtieth-street, died suddenly last Thursday, of apoplexy. Yesterday was a very lively day at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and, with the exception of 10 minutes for lunch, Justice Murray never left the bench from 8:30 A.M. until after 5 P.M. The most important and interesting case brought before him was that of Roundsman Francis J. McCarthy, of the Twentieth Precinet Police, who was arrested for burglary.

When Coroner Gaffney entered the Village Hall of Stapleton last evening he found all the inhabitants of the village that the hall would hold assembled to gaze at him and Richard Rollason, the Englishman who shot and killed George Sisk early on the morning of the Fourth of July.

LONDON, July 9. The British troop-ship Orontes, from Simon's Bay, South Africa, having on board the body of the late Prince Imperial of France, was sighted off Eddystone Light at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and is expected to arrive in Spithead water at midnight, where the body will be transferred to the Admiralty yacht Enchantress, for conveyance to the Royal Military Academy at Woolwich.

From recent developments, it seems that entire harmony does not exist between the officers of the companies composing the marine insurance pool. Yesterday a reporter learned that Mr. W. R. Crowe11, President of the association, had issued a call for a full meeting of the pool at Niagara Falls on the 10th inst.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, July 9. William Teets, a well-known and respectable farmer, living 10 miles south-west of this city, was murdered yesterday afternoon with a club in the hands of William Pickering. The act seems to have been caused by family troubles.

The excellent racing that has distinguished the present meeting of the Monmouth Park Association bids fair to continue to the end, for the programme of to-day is very interesting. It is known as the Oaks or Ladies day, and the six races, present features that will arouse considerable enthu siasm.

LONDON, June 28. There is an epidemic of bad behavior in Senatorial assemblies. First, it is "a scene in the English Parliament." Then it is a contest between Bismarck and the constitutional representatives of Fatherland. Follows a tumult in the Assembly at Versailles; a Bonapartist Senator has literally to be turned out of the chamber.

WASHINGTON, July 9. First Lieut. J.C. Davenport, Ninth Cavalry, now on leave of absence, will report for temporary duty to Major R.N. Scott, in this city, who has charge of the publication of the official records of the rebellion.
Postmaster-General Key and family are now in the City, and are the guests of Postmaster James.

The inhabitants and property-owners in the Village of East New-York are still excited over the action of the Eastern Railroad Company in attempt ing to lay a single narrow-gange track on the south side of Atlantic avenue and across a siding of the Long Island Railroad Company.
Nevada City, Cal., has a new campaign paper called the Mudsill.

Shafer that the manuscript copy of the City ordinances, as recently codified by himself and Mr. Elliot F. Shepherd, who were appoined Commissioners for that purpose, was interpolated and tampered with, commenced to take testimony on the subject yesterday.

VINELAND, N.J., July 9. So far during the season the product of the Vineland fruit crops of those that have alreaay ripened and been harvested has not equaled the promise indicated by their condition in the early Spring months.
Mayor Howell is confined to his house by an attack of malarial fever.

LONDON, July 9. In the House of Commons last night the motion of Mr. Sampson Samuel Lloyd, Conservative, Chairman of the Associated Chambers of Commerce of the United Kingdom, in favor of the establishment of a Department of Agriculture and Commerce under a special Cabinet Minister, was, despite some objections by the Government, adopted by a vote of 76 to 56.

Robert Lynch, a painter, of No. 47 Elizabeth-street, was tried for highway robbery before Judge Cowing, in the General Sessions Court, yesterday. Lynch was jointly indicted with Daniel Murray, but he elected to be tried separately.

WARRENSBURG, Mo., July 9. Frank Davidson, who killed William Haggerty Sept. 21, 1878, and who was sentenced to be hanged to-day, spent a very restless night, and only slept from a little after 2 o'clock until 5 this morning. He was baptized this morning at 8:45 o'clock by Elder Foy, of the Christian Church.

WASHINGTON, July 9. The Commission created by the act of March 3 last to codify the Land laws, and alao to make recommendations with a view to important changes in the existing land system, organized in this city to-day.
It is reported that a large endowment some $500,000 is soon to be bequeathed by an aged and wealthy citizen of Baltimore for the benefit of sick children.

MAUCH CHUNK, July 8. The death of Judge Packer affected in a very slight manner the large interests in which he was interested. Though his property was estimated at $17,000,000 by those best competent to judge, it has not deteriorated one cent since his death, and the value of most of it has been enhanced. ATLANTA, Ga., July 3. Speaker Bacon has offered a bill regulating the trial of persons accused of any of the grades of homicide, which will, if it becomes a law, do a great deal toward the prevention of crime by assuring its speedy punishment. Soon after the killing of the late Col. R.A. Alston, Major Bacon outlined this measure in an interview with a reporter of the Atlanta Constitution.

OMAHA, Neb., July 9. The important announcement is made to-day that the Union Pa cific proposes building this year from a point on the line of the Republican Valley Branch to Lincoln, thence to Beatrice, thence to Marysville, Kan., intersecting there the St. Joseph and Denver City Line; ultimately to some point on the Kansas Pacific.

NORFOLK, Va., July 9. The following is the report of the Cotton Exchange on the condition of the cotton crop: Twenty eight replies from 20 counties in Virginia and North Carolina werd received; 12 report the weather in June very dry and cold; 16 report it as favorable; 24 report the weather more favorable in June than last year, and 4 not so favorable.

BERLIN, July 9. The debate on the Tariff bill was continued in the Reichstag to-day. Herr Windthorst defended Herr Frankenstein's motion to distribute the surplus revenue among the Federal States.

SARATOGA, July 10. The second day of the national regatta on the lake at this place has been as perfect as the first, and the beautiful weather has been fully appreciated and enjoyed by the rowing men and other visitors here present.
The Assembly committee continued its inquiry into the railway system of the State and its abuses yesterday in the County Court-house, Mr. Hepburn in the chair.

MEMPHIS, July 10. Many of the people of Memphis have been busy to-day getting out of the city. Everybody desires to leave before every other place is quarantined against Memphis. The offices of the various lines of transportation are crowded, and trains and steamers leaving the city within the next 48 hours will be crowded to their utmost capacity.
The fourth day of the Monmouth Park meeting was sigualized by a very good series of races and the general success of the favorites.

Mr. William B. Hackenburg, President of the Sixth Council of the Union of American and Hebrew Congregations, called the morning session of the Council to order at 9:30 A. M. yesterday, and ordered the Council to rise, while the Rev. Dr. Samuel Hirseh, of Philadelphia, led in prayer.

A new survey of the Passaic River is being made under the direction of Gen. Newton. Michael, McGuire was arrested in Newark yesterday for attempting to kill his wife with an axe. He was placed under $1,000 ball. The Dover Bank, (State,) of Dover, was absorbed yesterday by the National Union Bank of Dover. The accounts were transferred.

Some time ago suit was begun in Brooklyn by Mrs. Caroline Breimann to recover $200,000 damages from Mrs. Catharine Paash. The complaint charged that Mrs. Paash had estranged the affections of Mrs. Breimann's husband and induced him to break his marital vows.

To the novice in life insurance, the Equitable's recent "announcement" looks like a practical reform in business methods; to the well-advised, it appears in its true light an attempt to secure credit, praise, and prestige to which it has no rightful title.

The successful termination of the African journey of Major Serpa Pinto has already, thanks to the telegraph, gained him a European fame. He has been received with enthusiasm by all parties, and would seem to have revived traditions of old Portuguese glories, and to have put some new blood into their history.

Some fear appears to be entertained by the City Hall politicians of Brooklyn that Alderman Ray, President of the Common Council, will take advantage of Mayor Howell's illness to send to the Board of Aldermen, which has a Republican majority, names for the different commissions which will be acceptable to that body.

At this season complaints are frequent that the managers of excursion steam-boats, in their hurry to earn the largest amount of fares at the least expenditure, are very neglectful of the regulations imposed upon them for securing safety and comfort of passengers.

Charles N. Gordon was formerly cutter in the tailoring establishment of ex-Alderman Robert B. Morehead, of Paterson, N. J., and was considered a skillful and valuable workman.

WASHINGTON, July 10. Requests are received every day by the Attorney-General from United States Judges and Marshals for copies of the recent act of Congress making appropriations for judicial expenses for the current fiscal year.

It seems to be conceded that the British authorities decline to extricate Lord LORNE and his advisers from an ugly dilemma by sanctioning the dismissal of Lieut.-Gov. LETELLIER or otherwise assuming the responsibility of deciding a question which properly belongs to Canada alone.

Crook's Amateur Band will give a concert at the Battery this evening. A large and brilliant display of pyrotechnics is promised to-morrow evening at Manhattan Beach. John Hope, convicted of complicity in the Manhattan Bank burglary, is to be brought up for sentence in the General Sessions Court today.

At 3:30 P.M. yesterday the mercury rose to 90 . Car-drivers mopped their faces with dingy pieces of cambric, and the apple-woman on the corner lost her usual avidity for driving n bargain with unsalable bananas.

WASHINGTON, July 11 1 A.M. The barometer continues highest over the Gulf of Mexico, but has fallen at nearly all stations, and is nearly everywhere below the normal, being lowest in the Northwest and ovar the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

The members of the Vermont Editors' and Publishers' Association are out for a hoilday, and have taken in New-York on their travels. This excursion is the supplement to their tenth annual meeting, and has been so far quite delightful.

Bishop Seymour and his sister left the City yesterday afternoon, the former to fill a number of clerical engagements, and the latter to go to Rondout for her health. She was accompanied by her son-in-law, Mr. Francis O. Montgomery. and his wife. Mrs. Seymour is well advanced in years, and has been in feeble health for some time.

The history of the crime for which Buzzell was hanged is one of the most remarkable, as well as interesting, on record. He had for years been the intimate friend of Susan A. Hanson, of Brookfield, and it was generally known that they were engaged. Buzzell suddenly broke the engagement, and soon after was compelled to marry a young woman when he had ruined.

PORTSMOUTH, July 10. The coffin containing the body of the Prince Imperial was removed from the troop-ship Orontes to the Admiralty yacht Enchantress, at 8 o'clock this morning. Minute-guns were fired. Prince Murat was present.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 10. The news of the outbreak of yellow fever in Memphis caused some excitement here to-day. Business men, remembering the disastrous effects of last year's epidemic upon trade, feel much anxiety.
By the provisions of recent acts of Congress, as construed by the Post Office Department, various important modifications have been made in rates of postage and in the clasaification of mail matter.
The Rapid Transit Commissioners were in session all day yesterday, and they expect to finally pass upon the plans and specifications for the construction of the roads which they have laid out today.

It was learned yesterday that the ThirdAvenue Railroad Company had recently discharged a large number of their conductors and drivers for entering into a conspiracy to defrand the company by tampering with the indicators, or "monitors," as they are termed, which are supposed to accuratley record the passengers' fares.

MADRID, July 10, The Libertad states that the Emperor of Austria will, during the coming Autumn, receive a communication from Madrid relative to the projected alliance between King Alfonso of Spain and the Archduchess Marie of Austria. The communication will be officially published in November.
Mahor Oriu Hathc, of Fond du Lac, is in the field as a candidate for the Greenback nomination for Governor of Wisconsin.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 11. Stevens Co., a portion of which building was leased and used by Adams Setzer.

BERLIN, July 11. On the third reading of the Tariff bill in the Reichstag to-day, a motion by Herr Reichensperger, of Crefeld, for a reduction of the duties on cotton goods, was rejected. The clauses relative to cotton were adopted substantially in the same form as on the second reading. The motion of Herr Stumm, to increase the duties on iron, was adopted.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 13. Soon after daylight this morning, the Corinthians of the Seawanhaka Yacht Squadron, now on its cruise to the eastward, who spent yesterday at anchor off the Pequot House, New-London, were astir and making ready for their run to Newport.

A person who is connected with THE TIMES by writing occasional accounts of fires, murders, and other Metropolitan amusements for its columns, sometimes styled a reporter, took a trip to Coney Island yesterday in the good old style of three or four years ago.

That most popular of all fruits grown in America the peach will make its appearance in the market this week in quantities large enough to make it the chief attraction there. Maryland and Delaware will begin to gather their crops this week.

BERLIN, July 13. The Tariff bill, as passed by the Reichstag, includes amendments providing that the grain duties shall come into force on the 1st of January, 1880, and the duty on flax on the 1st of July, 1880.

SOMERVILLE, N.J. July 13. It seems as though each county in New-Jersey was destined to investigate the actions of its Boards of Freeholders, especially all those counties whose boards are controlled by Democrats.

Work upon the Central Pacific Company's new monster ferry-boat, the Solano, now building at West Oakland, has been pushed ahead so rapidly that it will soon be ready for launching. She is much longer, even, than the City of Peking, and has a greater width of beam than any vessel afloat.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 13. John Shufelt, the North Egremont laborer arrested on suspicion of murdering his wife, has been lodged in the County Jail, and diligent efforts are being made to unravel the mysteries of the case before the hearing in the District Court, appointed for next Friday.

James Tracy, the bar-keeper in the saloon of Thomas Campbell, at No. 443 Grand-street, was shot in the hip by Rodey Phalen, during a quarrel in the saloon yesterday morning, and seriously hurt. WASHINGTON, June 8. The Republic, a weekly journal, published in Washington, and edited in the Radical style of journalism, attacks Gens. Beauregard and Early on account of their connection with the Louisiana lottory.

Turfmen in every section of the country are now looking toward or starting for Saratogs, for the great meeting of the year is to begin there on Saturday next. Racing at all other points ceases, and the attention of the entire truf world is concentrated on the Saratoga course, where the East and West, North and South, come into conflict and strive for supremacy.

CHICAGO, July 13. The railroads leading east from this city are doing a much smaller business now than they had been doing before the late advance in rates went into effect.

VIENNA, July 13. The elections for the Reichsrath have terminated. They resulted in the return of 173 members of the various Liberal groups, and 175 Conservatives and Nationalists. Three of those elected have declined to sit, and two have been elected each for two places, thus rendering five supplementary elections necessary.

Mr. Beecher spoke, in his sermon yesterday morning, of the death of young Louis Napoleon Bonaparte as an event "calculated to bring to mind a thousand years of history." Among the thousands who are seeking new pleasures this Summer across the Ocean, probably only a few are aware how varied and original are our own Summer resorts in the United States. No European country offers such a variety, because none has such an extended coast-line or such a variety of climates.

WASHINGTON, July 13. There are 37 vacancies in the rank of Second Lieutenant in the Army, which it is proposed to fill this week by appointments from civil life. These vacancies are in addition to those recently filled by the assignment of the last graduating class of the Military Academy.

LONG BRANCH, July 13. It was evident more than a month ago that the annual preparations for the reception of Summer visitors were much further advanced that at the corresponding periods in previous years, showing the faith of the landlords in their roseate anticipations then recorded in these columns.

Some alarm was caused in Jersey City yesterday morning by reports printed in several of the New-York papers respecting a number of cases of a mysterious disease alleged to have broken out in the tobacco factory of Lorillard Co., an establishment five stories high, occupying a square abutting upon Bay, Washington, and contiguous streets.

A fashionable church out on West Walnutstreet has a Rector who has been placed in embarrassing positions simply because of his absent-mindedness. CHICAGO, July 14. The Tribune's special from Denver to-night gives the particulars of the decision to-day upon the important cases involving the Denver and Rio Grande and Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroads. Justice Miller announced the views of the court upon the question at issue.

WASHINGTON, July 14. The Executive Committee of the National Board of Health invites the attention of all State and municipal authorities and sanitary organizations to the fact that they should, without delay, endeavor to secure the best sanitary condition of the places and people under their charge.

LONDON, July 14. The Times says: "Sir Stafford Northcote, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is expected to-night to make a statement in the House of Commons as to what measures the Government will find it necessary to abandon for the present session of Parliament because of a lack of time.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 14. The subject of yellow fever is now scarcely mentioned. Incoming trains and steamers are crowded with returning people, and the feeling of security has become general. No new cases of yellow fever have been reported. Mrs. Tobin, residing in Bradford street, died at 6 o'clock this morning and was buried at 8.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., July 14. The Old Colony Railroad freight engine has been stopped from going inside the State Prison yard to take out the two cars which are loaded daily with the manufactured products of the institution. The cars are now pushed out by hand, while those containing the Prison supplies are "kicked" into the yard by the locomotive.

WASHINGTON, July 14. In an interview published in the Star of to-day, William E. Chandler gives his views upon the political outlook. In reference to the national campagn of 1880, Mr. Chandler expresses the belief that Tilden has the best chance for the Democratic nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14.--The Hon. John Sherman, Secretary of the Treasury, was the recipient of marked attention here to-day at the hands of the members of the Maritime Exchange and others. WASHINGTON, July 14. The intelligence from Europe, printed in the newspapers of Saturday last, contained the following dispatch from Berlin: "The negotiations between Russia and the United States relative to the fisheries near Alaska have resulted in an arrangement by which vessels of the United States are allowed to fish in Russian waters in return for the payment of a money compensation."

John Cooke, of Richmond, Yorkshire, England, has begun a suit in the Supreme Court against the stockholders of the New-York, Boston and Montreal Railway Company and others, to have the sale of the bonds to him and 37 other British bondholders set aside and declared void and fraudulent.
California Republican newspapers continue to speak encouragingly of the prospects of success in the coming election.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., July 11. Society in Evansville was greatly shocked this afternoon by the suicide of Mrs. Dr. J.W. Irwin, a lady moving in the highest society here, and very warmly admired by a large circle of friends. Dr. and Mrs. Irwin have been married only seven weeks, the bride having been Miss Stella Mather, of Fostoria, Ohio, daughter of the Rev. D.D. Mather, of the Methodist church there.

Michael Travis, who was stabbed in the breast by Paul Shirley, near the ferry-house on Fulton street, Brooklyn, died of his wounds in the City Hospital at an early hour yesterday morning. There seems to be no dispute as to the origin of the quarrel which led to the stabbing. Shirley, who is a night clerk employed by the Western Union Telegraph Company, lives at No. 2 Harris-court.

A deal of litigation is occasioned in the world by dead people, not only those who leave a will which does not suit the surviving relatives, but those who take the liberty of dying without disposing of their property at all. A curious case was recently decided in an English court, but as an appeal has been taken, the lawyers are not done with it yet.

LONDON, July 3. A blue sky, promising a week of sunshine, which has not been verified; crowds of people lining flag-decked streets; flash of blue and red and many flaunting colors; and my hansom cab at last pulls up at the entrance of the international show of the Royal Agricultural Society. The scene is Kilburn, a north-western suburb of London.

BERLIN, JulY 14. The 17 National Liberals who, on Saturday last, seceded from that party, constituted a section headed by the historian Treitschke. Their secession was due to a vote of censure passed upon them by a majority of the party for supporting Prince Bismarck's views on the tariff.

LAKE PROVIDENCE, La., July 14. On Wednesday evening last, about 6 o'clock, a murderous scene took place in Lake-street, near the centre of the business portion of the town. S. L. Austin, Sr., was killed outright; his son, the Parish Judge, was mortally wounded, and an industrious colored man, W.H. Smith, was killed by a stray shot.

Several Paymasters in the Army were lately appointed from civil life; and now, althdugh the Army is notoriously overoffcered, thirty-seven vacancies in the rank of Second Lieutenant are to be filled in the same way. In the latter case, the vaeancies exist after the members of the graduating class from West Point have been assigned to duty.

John Cash, the Twentieth Ward prize-fighter, who was arrested Sunday morning in Jacob Munzinger's stable, fresh from a prize-fight with John Moore, the Buffalo "unknown," was arraigned before Justice Wheeler, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, for trial.

The annual picnic of the Germania Schuetzen Bund, of West Hoboken, which took place on Sunday afternoon and evening, was a very disorderly affair. In order to make it more successful, the West Hoboken Bund invited the Hudson City Bund, also called the Germania Schuetzen Bund, and the secaucus Horse Troop to accompany them.

The Union-Square company will begin an engagement in Chicago on the 28th inst. In all probability, "The Banker's Daughter" will be the first play produced. Miss Ellie Wilton will fill the part that Miss Jewett played in this City.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday for the last time previous to the Summer recess. Alderman Ray, President, in the chair. After the transaction of some routine business, Alderman Kenna moved that the name of William H. Murtha, sent in by the Mayor for the office of Register of Arrears, be taken from the table.

One of the quaintest and most peculiar female characters this country ever produced was Moll Pitcher, the famous fortune-teller, who resided at Lynn, but who was of Marblehead extraction. The trouble among the deck-hands, stevedores, and firemen employed on the steam-boats of the New-Haven, Hartford, and Bridgeport Lines, which at one time threatened to result in a strike, has been settled, and for the present quiet reigns among them, and they are comparatively contented and happy.

DETROIT, Mich., July 14. The Michigan oarsmen have all returned from Saratoga. The Wyandoties got back quietly on Saturday with their Toledo laurels. Their friends claim that only their mistake as to the finish line in the trial heats prevented them from participating in final heats of fours. The Zephyrs and Michigans, of this city, also got home on Saturday.

MEMPHIS, July 15. The city remains very quiet. No new cases are reported, and in a few days it is expected all the quarantine restrictions now in force against Memphis will be removed. Norfolk, Va., has taken the initiative and through cars will go to that city to-night.

Stanley Huntley, the energetic Bohemian who penetrated the buffalo country north of the Missouri and interviewed Sitting Ball face to face, being the first white man to enter the Teton camp since the Custer massacre, has reached this city on his return East, and has a thrilling story to tell about his experiences.

ELIZABETHTOWN, Hardin County, Ill., July 14. There exists in one portion of this county, known as "Cave-in-Rock," on the Ohio River, a village of about 1,000 inhabitants, a condition of affairs bordering on barbarism. Two rival families and their adherents for years have kept the community in a state of abject fear, and a reign of terror has prevailed which is a disgrace to any civilized community.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 26. A few steps beyond the sign-post on the road to Marietta which bears the words "To Atlanta 6 miles," stands an old-fashioned country house, two stories high. Here, with his wife Susan, Mr. Defoor has lived since that time, respected and esteemed by his neighbors.

MEMPHIS, July 27. The lists of new yellow fever cases and interments for the last 24hours do not give much encouragement, and are particularly discouraging to the opinion which prevailed all day that the disease was abating.

The feud between Virchow and Haeckel which has been rankling for years, and which burst forth some time ago in a lecture delivered by the veteran Virchow before a meeting of Naturalists in Munich, was not likely to slumber through any submissiveness on the part of Haeckel, the former disciple of Virchow.
The dividends payable in Boston in August aggregate $2,533,068.

You will have heard long since of the arrival of the Mahroussa in Naples, on Thursday night, with the ex-Khedive of Egypt on board. He was not expected before the 8th or 9th inst., so that his Highness came in quite unexpectedly. The Khedive slept on board, and up to the latest reports had not landed.

SIMLA, July 26. Major Cavagnari and the members of the British mission arrived at Cabul on the 24th inst. They were received with brilliant military honors and salutes. The demeanor of the populace was respectful. Yakoob Khan replied in very friendly terms to the speech made by Major Cavagnari on presenting his credentials.

It has been well known to all those familiar with the history and career of the Rev. Dr. Justin D. Fulton, of the Centennial Baptist Church, in Brooklyn, that his aim during the six years which he has spent in Brooklyn has been to establish a great free church, where he could preach to and work for the poor.
At the Prince of Wales's Theatre, London, the new play, adapted from Sardou, will be produced on the 27th of September.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 21.--This morning about 2 o'clock Mr. E. H. Thomas, proprietor of the United States Hotel at this place, was awakened by his wife, who said she thought the hotel was on fire.

In 1841 Alanson Work, a citizen residing at the Mission Institute, near Quincy, III., with two young men, named Burr and Thompson, theological students in the school, were seized by an armed band while attempting to aid in the escape of fugitive slaves from Missouri, and sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment in the penitentiary of that State.
The Hon. Zachariah Allen, whose services to the Town and City of Providence have been as varied as they were valuable, was actively connected with the old volunteer Fire Department.

NEW-HAVEN, July 27. The most aristocratic street in this city is Hillhouse-avenue; its length is only two blocks, and it extends from Wall-street to Sachem-street. At its northern end lies the old Hillhouse property-a large private park, finely wooded, with the Hillhouse mansion near its centre.

WASHINGTON, July 27. Complaints are frequently made, through the newspapers and by letters to the Treasury Department, of the searcity of one and two dollar notes, and the opinion prevails that this scarcity is caused by the Treasury Department withholding notes of those denominations.

PARIS, July 14. Notwithstanding Gen. Saussier's assurances that the Algerian insurrection had been quelled, that the brilliant sucesses of Gen. Forgemol's expeditionary column had stamped out every sympton of disaffection with French rule in Africa, the Republique Francaise does not affect to conceal its opinion that all danger has not passed with the repression of the disorders in the Aures.
A burglar who was convicted at Bedford last Saturday seems to have been one of the mildestmannered men that ever burgled, if we may be pardoned the use of a convenient Americanism.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 27. A serious affray occurred at the Slade Mill about 5 o'clock this afternoon. Some striking spinners, who allege that while passing the mill they were shouted at by working spinners, created a disturbance, and a crowd, numbering from 500 to 1,000 persons, soon gathered.

The placing of the sulphate of quinine on the free list is so recent an occurrence that it is hardly possible as yet to judgo whether the country will be benefited by it or not. Legislative action in respect to quinine, as such things generally are, was hasty and precipitate.

Not less than 20,000 people went to Rockaway yesterday, lounged on tho states and verandas and under the cedars, clambered wearily along the clay roads, bathed, ate their stewed clams, and drank their lager, not knowing that the abolition of Sunday lager was threatened.

A report came recently from Newport that branches of the Boston and New-York Stock Exchanges are to be oponed there at once, and that their opening will increase the attractiveness of the renowned wateringplace.

BALLSTON SPA, July 25. Stopping over a train at this once famous watering place, which, though it long since lost its hold as a fashionable resort, is yet one of the prettiest and freshest-appearing villages in the State or country, your correspondent met Mr. Charles W.S. Heaton, long time a resident of New-York, and known for his inventive genius.

GLEN COVE, July 27. A more unpromising day on which to start on a pleasure excursion than yesterday can hardly be imagined, but it was the day appointed for the beginning of the Atlantic Yacht Club cruise to the eastward, and despite the weather the start was effected and the first run of the cruise, from Whitestone to this place, was made.

Rosario Murano, Felix Bamoute, John Minoco, and Matthew Murano, four Italians, quarreled while playing cards at No. 314 Mott-street on Saturday. Bamoute stabbed Rosario Murano twice in the back, inflicting dangerous wounds.

By the Common Council, the flags of the city were ordered to float today in honor of the one hundred and seventy-eighth anniversary of the founding of Detroit. The circumstances under which the founder of this goodly city happened to sit down here are therefore pertinent to this occasion.

PITTSBURG, July 27. The heavy storm of yesterday morning was productive of much damage throughout the country, Special dispatches from the oil country and other points report railroads washed away and towns inundated. In this city no damage was done beyond the filling of some cellars with water and the flooding of some sewers.

About 250 cabinet-makers, joiners, and others occupied in wood-working, hold a meeting at the Germania Assembly Rooms, yesterday morning, to discuss the advisability of demanding a reduction of the time of labor each day to eight hours. L. Schrader was elected Chairman. B. Kaufmann, a cabinet-maker, was the first speaker.

Whitney, counsel for the Society for the Prevention of Crime, was before Justice Kilbreth in the Fifty-seventh-Street Police Court, yesterday morning, to prosecute David Porter and Patrick Nolan, the two men captured when Sergt. Suttle raided the gambling house at No. 1 Firststreet, corner of Bowery, on Saturday evening. Charles S. CINCINNATI, July 28. An experiment in local politics was tried by the Republicans today, which consisted of holding a, monster convention for the nomination of county officers and a legislative ticket. The convention met in the great music hall.

SARATOGA, July 28. After a week of cloud and rain, the sun shone from an almost cloudless sky this morning, and Saratoga assumed its wonted gayety. The horses had a good track to run over once more, and the prospect of a fine day's sport drew a large attendance of spectators.

Senor J.A. De Lavalle, Peruvian Minister to Brazil, arrived in this City yesterday and took rooms at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. He is on his way to his post of duty, having been obliged, on account of the war, to come to New-York and take the steamer to Rio de Janeiro, in order to avoid the Chilian cruisers.

LONDON, Aug. 7.--Financial articles published this morning state that the withdrawal of gold from the Bank of England yesterday for the United States was the probable precursor of larger shipments in payment for quantities of American produce arriving here and in France, and that the steady decline in the rates of exchange has pointed to such a movement in bullion for some time past.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 7.--Political affairs in Jefferson County and Northern NewYork are beginning to be interesting. There seems to be an unusual interest in the State canvass, and a great deal is said about the men who have been mentioned for offices.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 7.--Twenty-five new cases and five deaths form the startling report from the books of the Board of Health today. It is difficult to ascertain the truth about this apparent spread of the disease.

SARATOGA, Aug. 7.--The second regular day of the August meeting was one of intense excitement, and will not be forgotten by the people who were present, especially the heavy betting men, who were slaughtered to a greater extent than on any previous day this season. All the favorites were beaten one after another, and the outsiders reaped a rich harvest.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 7.--The Congressional election investigation was resumed to-day.

GUMBO SOUP, (AS MADE IN FLORIDA.)--One chicken, fried brown; one gallon water, four slices of ham; put this on the fire to cook slowly from 8 o'clock to 12 M.; have ready one quart of okra, chopped fine, one pint green corn, one pint tomatoes, peeled, one onion, chopped fine: salt and pepper to taste. Let all cook till done--AUNT JULIA.

Mr. Joseph Plummer is a farmer, who lives in the Town of Durham. Although he is apparently nearing his three score years, his form is as straight as an arrow. He is tall, clean-limbed and muscular --a man that burglars don't want to trifle with if they know when they are well off.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 9.--Twenty-five new cases and five deaths were reported to the Board of Health to-day; 10 of the new patients are white and 15 colored. The deaths were all of white persons-Mrs. Frances Getz, Mrs. A. Boyd, L. Tabler, Miss Lizzie Getchell, and L. Roberts.

A Preston farmer, finding that rats were making sad havoc with the provender in his cellar; purchased a cat that was recommended as a mouser. For a while after not a rat was to be seen, and their depredations ceased entirely. This apparent success made the old man boast that "Tab was more'n a ordinary cat," and the animal soon had the full confidence of the whole family.

The Greenpoint Athletic Club gave an interesting exhibition of open handicap games on their grounds, on Van Cott avenue, between Eckford and Oakland streets, Greenpoint, yesterday afternoon, which was witnessed by a large number of athletes well-known in amateur circles.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 9.--Until within a few days ago we have had a charming variety of political parties in this the youngest and most active county in Pennsylvania, but recently the Democratic-Labor, the original Greenback, and the straight-out Reformers have formed a fusion under the aegis of the Democratic Party, and at the dictation of Mr. Beamish, who rules once more in this region.

BOSTON, Aug. 6.--Although I am Bostonbred. I never come back to the dear old city without noticing something that is peculiar to Boston--a Boston notion, as it were. In a smaller town we should call such things provincial but here they are only notions.

The late Mr. Metealfe, whose will has just. been disputed by some of his relations, is said to have labored under some curious and not altogether consistent delusions. Thus, he held that "her Majesty had had no right to the throne, and that the right lay with him," though he considerately added that "he would not enforce it."

GREENPORT, Aug. 9.--Everybody who has examined a map of Long Island carefully enough knows that its eastern end is shaped not unlike the claw of a lobster. It is divided by Gardiner's Bay and its branches and the two Peconic Bays into two narrow and tapering peninsulas.

OMAHA, Aug. 10. Great interest, especially among stock shippers, is manifested in the freight war, which broke out yesterday between the Union Pacific and Burlington and Missouri Railroads, whereby the rate of both roads between Kearney and Omaha on all kinds of freight is reduced to 5 cents per hundred. Heretofore, pool rates have existed on both roads from Kearney eastward.

HOT SPRINGS, Wyoming, July 28. One of your lady residents is, at this writing ranked as a heroine by the natives of this wild, both whites and Indiana. Miss Maggie Foreman, who came to the mountains a few days since, to visit relatives, has accomplished a feat of which few hunters can boast.
A Tax-reduction State Convention is to be held in Baltimore, Md., to-morrow. The meeting of the Democratic State Committee is to be held at Niagara Falls on Friday next.

The markets of the City were as fully supplied with good peaches last week as THE TIMES of last Monday promised they would be. The fruit was principally of the Troth's Early variety, and the prices were lower than most fruiterers anticipated. It is a very pretty, red fruit, highly colored, and of good flavor.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 11.--The weather is clear and exhilarating, but a grave-yard silence prevails. The number of new cases reported to the Board of Health to-day was 34 in the city, and 11 outside the corporation limits.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 11--The residence of the Rev. James Demerest, of the Second Reformed Dutch Church of this place, was entered by burglars last night, but as the family are absent and all their valuables deposited in the kingston Bank, the thieves got no booty. They were given a lively chase by Roundsineu Beadle and Relyea, but the officers failed to identify them.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--H.L. Hallett, Chief Supervisor of Elections, was examined by the Wallace Investigating Committee to-day. He testified that he was appointed in 1872, and acted as Supervisor at the November election of 1878; he took the lists of voters on the State registry and put them into the hands of Supervisors in each district, with instructions to report the names of those who they thought ought not to vote.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13.--The Dental Convention reassembled at 9:30 o'clock. Dr. Winder, of Baltimore, read a paper on dental organization, recommending the formation of a permanent representative national body by the fusion of this body with the Southern Dental Association and the American Dental Association.

QUEBEC, Aug. 13.--In the Legislature last night a vote was taken on Mr. Chapleau's motion of non-confidence in the Government as regards its railroad policy, and the Government was sustained by a majority of two. Mr. Shehyn, a Government supporter, voted with the Opposition.

The sessions of the fourth annual convention of the National Cotton Exchange were begun yesterday in the board-room of the Equitable Assurance Company, Mr. John Phelps, of New-Orleans, calling about 35 delegates to order shortly before 12:30 P.M. Prior to that hour the Executive Council were in session arranging the order of business for the convention.

Secretary EVARTS, it is reported, has prepared a circular to be sent to the various diplomatic agents of the United States, at foreign posts, relating to the attitude of the United States Government toward Mormon polygamy.

There is much excitement in Brooklyn over the local political situation. Mayor Howell has been confined to the house by severe illness for saveral weeks, and William H. Ray, President of the Board of Aldermen, is now Acting Mayor.

ALBANY, Aug. 13.--The following complete the July reports of the City savings banks: The 25 banks now doing business on July 1 reportod aggregate assets of $189,650,693 51; due depositors $168,721,692 92; surplus, $20,823,604 07; open accounts, 436,056; accounts opened since Jan. 1, 45,281; and accounts closed, 33,434. The deposits received during the last six months amounted to $23,934,885 80.
A fire was discovered by the night watchman about 1 o'clock yesterday morning in the second story of A. Kipp Co.'s engine manufactory, on Main-street, in the Village of Sing Sing.
CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 13.--The opening event to-day was a concert by the North-western Band, of Meadville, at the Palace Hotel Park.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 13.--In this city and at Narragansett Pier the accounts of the Canonchet affair published in THE TIMES have been read with great interest.
The Baltimore Evening Bulletin says that the managers of the Abbott Rail Mill are considering the advisability of starting the mill on full time, in anticipation of a demand for rails.

The annual tax bills of Elizabeth, N.J., are being distributed, and the Treasurer expects in a few days to be in funds. In the meantime the creditors are becoming clamorous, and are quarreling among themselves as to who shall take precedence in the matter of payment.

City Marshal Stone and Officer Mears, of Lynn, arrested a young woman named Ida M. Eddy at one of the hotels in Nahant yesterday afternoon upon a charge of publishing her own death in the Lynn Record of Aug. 29, 1878, and the Lynn Item of June 6, 1879.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13.--After the excitement of yesterday there necessarily came a reaction, and, consequently, the attendance of spectators to-day was small. The weather was fine, however, and the track very fast. The sport was excellent. Only one of the favorites was successful. The three-quarters dash was won by Oriole, the mile and three-quarters by General Phillips, the mile and an eighth by Lancewood, and the mile by Rhadamanthus.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 13.--As Mr. Caleb Shreve and his wife, of Bordentown, were driving to this City yesterday, ashes from Mr. Shreve's cigar set fire to his wife's clothing, and she was terribly burned. She was taken to St. Francis Hospital, and is to-night in a dying condition.

United States Attorney Woodford returned yesterday from the Catskills, where he has been for a few days, to represent the Government in a habeas corpus proceeding made returnable before Judge Strong, of the United States Supreme Court, at the Catskill Mountain House.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 13.--The weather to-day has been cloudy and warm, the thermometer ranging from 83 to 87 . Twenty-seven new yellow fever patients were officially reported to the Board of Health, of which 7 were white and 16 colored persons.

FALL RIVER, Aug. 13.--The city is again excited over reports of another defalcation. It has been rumored ever since the exposure of Treasurer Durfee's irregularities in using the mill funds to meet his "shorts" in speculations in cotton "futures," that other mill Treasurers were in a similar condition, and though exposures were expected, they are received as they come with impatience and indignation.

One of the most cleverly-executed swindles that has ever been successfully perpetrated in this city was put up on Lesser Friedberg, the notorious pawnbroker implicated in the outrageous murder of Police Officer Albert Race in front of his pawn-shop at No. 474 State-street in last October.

The Brooklyn Rifle Club arranged a grand sweepstakes match to be held on its new grounds at Locust Grove, Long Island, yesterday afternoon. All the prominent riflemen in this City and vicinity were invited to be present, but only two accepted the invitation.

BOSTON, Aug. 14.--The Wallace Investigating Committee resumed the hearing of evidence this morning. Very few persons were present. LONDON, Ontario, Aug. 15.--A young man named Moore, who was staying at a hotel here, was called upon last evening by Mr. Funkey, of Detroit, accompanied by a local datective. After some conversation, Moore admitted that he had betrayed the secret of the combination of the safe in Mr. Funkey's place of business, in Detroit, to a gang of burglars who, on Sunday night last, robbed it. He was taken to Detroit.

An elderly man, respectably dressed, stood at the prisoner's bar in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning, looking vacantly at the dingy ceiling. Officer Cooke, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, told Justice Flammer that the prisoner had seized him by the coat and refused to go with him when he undertook to arrest him for slight intoxication. "How is this?" inquired the magistrate.

DETROIT, Aug.15.--The body of Annie Fleish ing, a woman of the town, who went on the steamer Steinhoff with a man named Pigeon,on the night of the fire, was found this morning in the river near the wreck. Both the man and the woman were under the influence of liquor on that night.
LONDON, Aug. 15.--It was reported yesterday that 100,000 worth of eagles were to be shipped to New-York to-day.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 15.--The resumption of the hearing of the charges against the Lelands for selling beer and liquors at the varions pavilions on the bluff in front of the Ocean Hotel, and in the immediate vicinity of the iron pier, has been the subject of general discussion for several days past.

Mr. Granville P. Hawes, of No. 134 West Forty-fourth-street, went from the City on the 3d of last June to spend the season traveling, taking his family with him. He left his residence, elegantly furnished, in charge of a man and his wife. Mr. Hawes returned to the City on the 11th inst, and discovered that his housekeepers had gone. All his efforts to find them were in vain.

QUEBEC, Aug. 15.--The trouble among the ship laborers culminated to-day in a free fight between the French Canadian and Irish factions. The fight occurred in the Lower Town, in Champlain-street, near tho wharf of Allan, Rae Co. The trouble began by the secession of Section No. 5 from the parent society, because the members of the section considered that they had notbeen properly treated.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15.--This season's cruise, of the New-York Yacht Club to the eastward, ends here to-night, the run from Vineyard Haven to this place having been made to-day. After the very pleasant hop given in honor of the club at the Sea View House, Oak Bluffs, last night, the yachtsmen returned at midnight to their yachts lying in Vineyard Haven, to enjoy a peaceful night's rest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--The War Department has recalled General Orders No. 10 of 1879, containing instructions relative to purchases and contracts for military supplies and services, and after subjecting the matter contained therein to careful revision and correction, has now republished it in General Orders No. 72, for the information and guidance of all concerned.

WINONA, Minn., Aug. 15.--While it remains true that the aggregate yield of wheat in Minnesota this year is considerably greater than it was a year ago, the results of the harvest just closed, as they are being daily developed, materally lower the anticipations of the yield, which were entertained in consequence of the generally healthy and luxuriant appearance of the plant during the season of growth.

The Police Commissioners held a meeting yesterday, all the Commissioners being present. Commissioner French was elected President for the week ending Aug. 22. Commissioner MacLean moved to erase from the minutes of the meeting of Aug. 2 all reference to the appointment of Sergeants and patrolmen, and suggested that the proposition to appoint additional patrolmen be referred to the Corporation Counsel.

A mere glance on the map shows the immense importance which Constantinople has for Russia. The principal item of Russian export is wheat, representing a value of about 100,000,000 rubles a year. Most of this wheat is grown in Southern Russia, and shipped from Odessa and other Black Sea ports to Leghorn, Marseilles, Barcelona, and London.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 15.--Mr. Platt made his appearance here with the Wallace Investigating Committee this morning, when it resumed its in quiry. The first witness was George G. Crocker, Chairman of the Young Republican Committee. He said that in the campaign, of 1878 he was Secretary of the Republican State Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug, 15.--The public sale, on Tuesday, by order of the United State Circuit Court, of the Pennsylvania and Delaware Railroad, marks the conclusion of an extremely disastrous chapter in railway financiering, affecting the South eastern portion of Pennslyvania, and the adjoining section of Delaware.

At the Modena Assizes, on the 24th of July, the famous brigand Paltrinierl, nicknamed " Biscla," was condemned to death. Two other brigands, Dozza and Galletti, were sentenced, the one to hard labor for life, the other to the same punishment for 20 years.

PARIS, July 30.--Hardly have we got rid of one Pretender to the French crown when another starts up. The Orleans Princes have not been talked about for many a day: since the collapse of the fusion scheme they appeared to have quietly accepted the position, to have become like all other French citizens.

Tuesday next will be the one hundredth anniversary of the Revolutionary battle of Paulus Hook, and the citizens have decided to have a celebration. The battle was one of the most brilliant and dashing exploits of "Light-Horse Harry " Lee.

A prominent merchant in Exchange-place, Saturday, stopped an American reporter to show him a sample of beet-root sugar, the contemplated manufacture of which, in this city, is receiving so much attention from both sugar men and farmers. The sample was brought from Rotterdam.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 11,--The mining of anthracite coal is an industry which occupies so much public attention on the mart, and is such an important factor in the everyday life of the community, that a leaf from the life of those actively engaged in it can scarcely fail to be interesting.

In France, Germany, and msst Continental countries, a man does not join his regiment till on an average he is 21, the minimum age being in theory 20. All medical authorities lay it down that a lad is not fit to undertake the hardships of active service till he is at least 20 years of age, and even that is too young.

In no place is the game of croquet more popular than in Philadelphia. There are five clubs of professionals, that is, of experts, as distinguished from novices. It is no uncommon thing for an expert in any of the clubs now organized in this city to make all the arches and constitute himself "rover," without once losing the balls.

QUEBEC, Aug. 16.--All remained quiet in the city during last night, except that in some of the streets pistol-shots were occasionally fired at random. The troops are still in their barracks. The Irish of the Champlain and Montcalm Wards are all prepared to defend their homes and families with their lives, and have barricaded their houses.
PARIS, Aug. 16.--A collision has occurred on the Argentan and Granville Railway. Four persons were killed and 30 injured.

SARATOGA, Aug. 16.--A cold north-east storm set in early this morning, but sufficient pressure had been brought to bear on the Executive Committee to have the races run, and a brass band was crowded into an omnibus, upon the sides of which it was announced that the races would take place, notwithstanding the rain. The attendance at the track was limited in numbers, only two ladies being present, white the track was a quagmire.

I have been keeping a restaurant for the past few years, and soft-shell crabs have been one of the great delicacies of my larder, the demand, however, being somewhat limited. Blushing is occasioned by suddan dilatation of the small blood-vessels, which form a fine network beneath the skin, and when they admit an increased volume of red blood cause the surface to appear suffused with color. Blanching is the opposite state, in which the vessels contract and squeeze out their blood, so that the sking is of its bloodless hue.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 16.--To-day's reports show 21 new cases and 7 deaths from yellow fever. The Board of Health reports the total number of deaths from yellow fever during the week ending at 6 o'clock this evening to be 46, end the total number to date since the first outbreak, 139.

The Quarantine Commissioners say that they intend to make application to Congress next Winter to give them without reserve the bulk of the Illinois, now used as a receiving-ship. Should Congress refuse, they will still need between $4,000 and $5,000 to make her fit for next season.

About 10:30 on Wednesday night, while Peter Demarest, of One Hundred and Forty-fourthstreet, near Third-avenue, was returning home through Willis-avenue from a church picnic at Hartung's Harlem River Park, he was suddenly attacked, knocked down, and robbed by two unknown men between One Hundred and Forty-first and One Hundred and Forty-second streets.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 21.--The fever is still spreading," is the general opinion expressed by medical gentlemen, and that sentiment is forcibly verified by the increased number of cases reported to-day.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21.--The tug Anna Belle, from the Lower Chesapeake, arrived at this port today, and brought up Capt. William Donnelly and two of the crew of the schooner John C. Henry, of Philadelphia, which was wrecked in the gale of Monday last. Capt. Donnelly and the two men were rescued from the wreck of the schooner by the German ship Agra, after having clung to the topmast all night.

The disagreement in the Park Commission has assumed such an aspect during the past few weeks that, unless some judicious chance is made before long in the personnel of the board, its affairs are likely to become irredeemably entangled.

John D. Wright, the President and founder of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, died at his residence, No. 29 West Thirty-eighth-street, yesterday, at 3 P.M. He had been feeble several years, but was not confined to his bed until Thursday a week ago. Mr. Wright was born at Rahway, N.J., Sept. 19, 1799. Two members of the Administration, representing somewhat different shades of Republican opinion, have in almost identical terms stated the limitation within which the practical results of the stalwart doctrine must be kept.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 21.--The six-week drought during June and July, provedless disastrous to the crops than was anticipated. Copious rains, at two or three days intervals since Aug. 1, have produced a wonderful change.

A generous public will learn with regret that a rupture has occurred between those estimable gentlemen, Mr. SAMUEL J. TILDEN and Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD. It has been supposed that these illustrious persons had much in common--in addition to their NewYork Elevated Railway stock.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21.--The corner stone of a new school building which D.L. Moody, the revivalist, proposes to erect in the northern part of the Village of Northfield, for furnishing academic instruction to pupils, was laid to-day.

The excellent Mr. BORIE, formerly Secretary of the Navy, went from Paris to Hong Kong, in the company of Gen. GRANT, to find out what the General's intentions were as to the next Presidential canvass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--The good intentions of Congress, looking to the establishment of a Government savings institution, by the circulation of the ten-dollar refunding certificates, have proved an utter failure.

Compilers of criminal statistics have neglected the most interesting phase of the subject with which they have had to deal. They have uniformly failed to consider crime as one of the industries of the country, offering to young men a career, attended with greater or loss chances of success or failure, of wealth or ruin, like other lines of business.
The France, from Havre, brought 117 immigrants yesterday. Ann Ritter, 50 years old, was found dead in bed, yesterday, at No. 67 Cherry-street.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 21.--The miners of this section view with considerable apprehension the threatened immigration of a considerable number of colliers from the old country upon what they say is false information regarding the condition of the Pennsylvania coalfields.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--At the opening of the session of the Bar Association to-day, E.J. Phelps, of Vermont, delivered an address on the rise and progress of constitutional law in this country.
Mr. Georgo Vandenhoff, the accomplished reader and actor, who is now traveling in Europe, will give another course of "Dickens Mornings" here next January.

Miss Belgarde's Julia--played by her last evening and on Tuesday evening at Haverly's Theatre--impresses us, more than her Rosalind did or could have done, with the conviction that she deserves encouragement.

LONDON, Aug. 7.--We are daily expecting the arrival of Lieut. Carey. People are beginning to talk a little more calmly about the young fellow, now that the excitement caused by the disaster is dying away. He is, I believe, to have a new trial, though the authorities are somewhat divided on the question.

Mr. Stephen J. Stillwell, Treasurer of the Town of Gravesend, is authority for the statement that the revenue to the town from its common lands, including Coney Island, last year was "about $12,000 after the expenses of the Land Commissioners were paid." So far this year Mr. Stillwell has received but $9,000.
The celebration of the battle of Paulus Hook, in Jersey City, cost the city about $1,425. Bills to the amount of $1,362.35 have already been ordered paid.

A telegram from Pittsfield, Mass., announces the death, at the advanced age of 79, of Dr. Jerome Van Crowninshield Smith, which occurred on Wednesday evening at the house of his sister in a little Berkshire village near that city.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 21.--The meeting which was addressed by Secretary Schurz in this city to-night in the City Hall attracted one of the largest and most appreciative audiences ever assembled in this city, and although 3,000 people were packed in the hall, twice as many found it impossible to gain admission. Ex-Gov. Dennison introduced the Secretary as "the gallant General and honest statesman."
Yesterday, in coming up the road, I witnessed a scene which to a "States man" could not but have a melancholy, though romantic, aspect. There was a bridal couple aboard the train.

Nearly all the vessels which arrived yesterday report that they met the hurricane of Monday last. Quantities of stuff from wrecks, and several small boats, bottom upward, have been passed along the coast, and quite a number of vessels which had been damaged during the storm were observed making the best progress they could toward port.

Goldsmith, Controller-General of the State, who is charged with high crimes and misdemeanors. Chief-Justice Warner presided. Six Managers from the House of Representatives--Messrs. COHOES, N.Y., Aug. 21.--Hugh Healy, the burglar who was shot by Sergt. Hodgson, of the Police force, while committing a robbery on July 2, and who has been in a critical condition ever since, died at his mother's residence at 1 o'clock this afternoon. The man has suffered terribly since the shooting.

There were 216 deaths, 250 births, and 35 marriages recorded at the Board of Health during the past week.

While visiting the country residence of his brother-in-law, ex-Congressman Morgan Jones, at East Moriches, Long Island, two weeks ago, Mr. Dennis Coppers, a well-known citizen of Hoboken, was killed by the accidental discharge of a shot-gun he was handling.

Superintendent Walling recently received from a young lady residing in Montgomery, Ala., package of doucments illustrative of the method by which she had been swindled out of $25 by one of the numerous firms of sharpers who makes alleged speculations in stocks the basis of a very good living at the expenses of fools throughout the country.
It is high time for the South to make itself heard, and in very plain language, in regard to Mr. Samuel J. Tilden and his assumed claims to the Democratic nomination for the Presidency in 1880.

The Atlantic Boat Club, of Hoboken, had their twenty-second annual regatta yesterday, at Pleasant Valley, and treated their friends to a very enjoyable spectacle, interspersed with a series of unpleasant mishaps to the contestants.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 21.--The anthracite coal trade, which has been pushed with such vigor this season that the production is now 6,000,000 tons greater than it was at this time last year, has so blocked the market that there has arisen a loud demand for a suspension of mining.

The death is announced by cable of Joseph Octave Delepierre, the Belgian historian and antiquary, who was for many years Consul-General of Belgium at London, and there published many of his most important works. Delepierre was born in the quaint old City of Bruges in 1804.
The committee on a revision of the rules of the House of Representatives, in session at the Elberon Hotel, Long Branch, during the past 10 days, has nearly completed its labors.

LONDON, Aug. 21.--The Times, in its financial article, says: "United States bonds are steady, in response to the demand for investment securities here. It is also stated that a very large amount in bonds was made up for transmission to New-York yesterday."

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 21.--A badly decomposed body was found under the bridge in the ferry-slip on the morning of the 13th inst. Coroner Schenck held an inquest, but the identity of the body was not established, nor was the cause of death ascertained. The body is now claimed to be that of "Jack" Horton, a resident of the Town of Wappingers, eight miles from Fishkill Landing.

The eighth annual regatta of the Tarrytown Yacht Club took place yesterday. The course was 20 miles from a stake boat anchored off the Tarrytown dock, to and around another off Dobb's Ferry, and return, this route to be sailed over twice.

ALBANY, Aug. 22.--Superintendent Smyth has just finished a series of important examinations of fire and life insurance companies, and a condition of affairs is shown that is likely to excite considerable public interest.

The incoming vessels continue to report very svere weather off the coast on Monday last, and but few of them have escaped without loss of spars or sails. The schooner Daylight, which arrived from a Virginian port yesterday, had on board the crew of the schooner Breeze, who had been compelled to abandon their vessel on the 19th.

The luxury or a saloon passage in a well-appointed transatlantic liner has often been described. The substantial comfort, the convenient arrangements, the excellent cuisine have been duly chronicled; the deference, attention, and civility shown to those who pay well have been eloquently catalogued and extelled.
Mayor Harrison, of Chicago, has laid before the City Council a project for establishing free baths. A mad wolf stampeded the population of Stringtown, Texas the other day. He was finally shot.

Little Rosalie Harris was shot in the head July 14, by John Beckett, who now lies in jail awaiting the result of her injuries. The ball was intended for her uncle, David Poindexter. It was fired from a 32-calibre revolver, and weighed half an ounce.

SARATOGA, Aug. 22.--At the meeting of the Railroad Committee to-day, Mr. Clark, General Freight Agent of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, was the first witness called to the stand, as he was compelled to leave Saratoga at noon. He testified that he was subordinate to Mr. Rutter, and in that gentleman's absence performed his duties; his regular business was the supervision of the freight department.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 22.--Two cases of yellow fever were brought to light to-day. One was reported by Dr. William M. Bailey, Sanitary Inspector of the First District. Both are near the Constance-street neighborhood. These are the first known cases which have occurred in 24 days, during which the city's deathrate has been exceedingly low.

The death of Mr. Joseph Severn does not absolutely sever the chain of literary reminiscences which unites this generation to that of Keats. There is still alive an English poet who remembers Keats as he was before fame, and even before censure, reached him, though the painter who watched his dying hours has departed.

Some of the pupils of Miss Kate Grant's swimming school gave an exhibition of their skill and endurance in the Harlem River, off One Hundred and Fourteenth-street, yesterday afternoon, and a fair share of the contestants showed themselves to be very proficient swimmers.

The only strong man in the Democratic Party of the State of New-York is SAMUEL J. TILDEN. This may not be saying much, but it is the truth nevertheless. He holds possession of the majority of the Democratic State Central Committee.

The passenger-lists of the outgoing steamships continue small, and but 168 cabin passengers are booked so far for the following steam-ships, which sail to-day: The Devonia and Victoria, of the Anchor Line; the City of New-York, of the Inman Line; the Neckar, of the North-German Lloyd, and the Spain, of the National Line.

LONDON, Aug. 22.--Mr. Albert Pell and Mr. Clare Sewell Read, members of Parliament, who are going to America in connection with the commission appointed to inquire into the agricultural depression in England, will leave on the Inman Line steamer City of Montreal, which sails from Liverpool on the 26th inst. for New-York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Further inquiry at the Treasury Department shows the following to be the relative cost of collecting the Customs at the four important ports on the Atlantic coast: At Boston the percentage on the dollar is .041; at New-York, .021; at Philadelphia, .034, and at Baltimore, .13.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday, at which Commissioners MacLean, French, and Morrison were present, Commissioner MacLean was appointed Acting President until the 29th inst. A writ of prohibition was served on the board restraining them from taking action in the case of Patrolman Charles O. Dooley, formerly of the Thirty-third, and now of the Eighteenth, Precinct, who was tried before Commissioner MacLean on Wednesday last for being absent from post.

The New-Haven Palladium says that the Pension Office has granted a pension to a man who was born in Connecticut, was bought and sold in Connecticut, and spent 25 years of his life here as a slave under the laws of Connecticut. Old James Mars, of Norfolk, Litchfield County, is the man.
LONDON, Aug. 22.--The report of Mr. Childers's resignation from the Board of Directors of the Great Western Railway is confirmed.

About three years ago publicity was given to a proposal by Mr. Holloway, of Oxford-street, Lon.don, and Tittenhurst, Sunninghill, Berks, to expend a considerable amount of money in the erection of a college for the higher education of women. Since that time time Mr. Holloway has purchased about 95 acres of land at Egham, near Virginia Water, known as the Mount Lee estate, and has vested the same in Trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22.--The schooner Julien Nelson, from New-Bedford, reports that on the 18th inst., at 7.30 P.M., she was struck by a hurricane which washed the boat astern. She scudded for seven hours. On the 20th inst., about 50 miles east-south-east of Sandy Hook, she saw the schooner Willie De Wolfe, of Calais, dismasted.

A dispatch from Reading to the Philadelphia Times says: "A most distressing affair took place this morning at the camp-meeting of the Evangelical Association, near Sinking Springs, this county, Mrs. Mary Deitzel, aged 65, a sister of the Presiding Elder, the Rev. J.M. Saylor, was so badly bitten by a copperhead snake, on the camp ground, that she was brought to Reading in an unconscious condition, and her life is despaired of.

The second Summer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association commences to-day. The meeting is filled with important races, and those of to-day are especially attractive. To commence with, there is a selling race, with allowances, for a purse of $500, dash of one mile, in which the beaten horses are not liable to be claimed.

--"A Murdered Nation," according to Felix L. Oswald, is the Circassian, which Russia has slowly crushed, dismembered, and now annihilated. The exodus which has been concluded by the expatriation of the highlanders of Mingrelia (a sort of Caucasian Montenegro) began in the Winter of 1864, when 200,000 Lesghian families were expelled from their mountain homes by order of the Czar.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 22.--The Greenback Party in Minnesota has never been of any importance, and is less in strength this Summer than ever. In the southern counties, where the party was strongest, the organization is going to pieces, and their members are returning to their former allegiance.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 5.--A resident of Pondoland telegraphs that hostilities are inevitable. It is stated from Pretoria that Sir Garnet Wolseley is convinced that the campaign against Chief Secocoeni in the north must be vigorously renewed.

After all his high-flown hopes and rosy promises, M. DE LESSEPS has been forced to withdraw his great Panama Canal project from the market for the present, because the shares have not been taken up with the alacrity that he expected.
