There was a great deal of excitement, and a great many emphatic expressions were indulged in at the Brighton Beach Fair Grounds yesterday afternoon. Some 1,500 or 2,000 persons were drawn together by the rumor which was circulated in this City and on Coney Island that Bramble was to run in one of the races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--1 A. M.--A storm of great energy, moving in a north-westerly track, has entered Texas. The barometer is low in NewEngland and the lower lake region, highest and falling in the South Atlantic States.

Mr. Samuel J. Tilden was busy with a host of callers at his Gramercy Park residence yesterday afternoon when a TIMES reporter called upon him and asked him to make a statement in respect to his connection with the elevated railroad enterprise. Mr. Tilden said he was pressed for time, but asked what the reporter wished to learn.

The Police-boat Seneca dropped down the river yesterday morning at 9.30 o'clock, from the dock at the foot of East Seventeenth-street. Among those on board were John B. Greene, Clerk of the Bureau of Street-cleaning; Isaac O. Hunt, Superintendent of Boats and Scows, and Capt. Henry Hedden, of the Metropolitan Police, Acting Inspector of the bureau.

LINCOLN, Me., Aug. 22.--Senator Blaine opened the canvass in Northern Maine to-day, at this place, a small town of 400 inhabitants, 50 miles north of Bangor. It is a Greenback stronghold, and was formerly as strongly Republican.

WARSAW, Aug. 22.--A court-martial here has condemned two peasants to four years' hard labor in the Siberian mines for opposing the demarkation of their plots of land, and six others to various terms of exile or imprisonment for the same offense.

It is not easy to retain a sober countenance while studying the solemn acknowledgements that come from Washington with regard to the non-fulfillment of the expectations excited by the issue of $40,000,000 of refunding certificates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--The records of the Treasury Department show a decided increase in the building of steam vessels this year over last. The reports for the last fiscal year have not all been received, although an estimate has been made which is thought to be nearly correct.

Prince Jerome Napoleon having been recently attacked by M. De Cassagnac and his friends, first, about his conduct in the Crimea, secondly on the speech made by him against the temporal power of the Pope, and thirdly on his candidature at Ajaccio at the general elections of 1876, M. D'Ornano, a Bonapartist Deputy, has taken up his defense.
The Alexandra Exhibition Company will give its last display of fire-works this evening at Manhattan Beach.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 22.--The investigation by Coroner Schenck over the dead body found in the Hudson, at Fishkill Landing, was resumed to-day, several witnesses being examined. One of the main questions to decide was the identity of the remains, as those who viewed the body when it was taken from the river on Aug. 13, although some of them were acquainted with "Jack" Horton, could not recognize him in the decomposed body before them.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 22.--At 1 o'clock last night a negro woke up an old lady named Lee, living near this city, and told her that her cows were out. She rushed out in her night-clothes to see about them, when the negro seized her and attempted to outrage her, saying: "D--n you, I'll cut your throat if you yell."

JAMAICA, Aug. 22.--The Republicans of the Second District of Queens County held their convention for the election of delegates to the State Convention in the Town-hall in Jamaica this afternoon. Embraced in the Second District are Long Island City and the three towns of Jamaica, Newtown, and Hempstead.

PANAMA, Aug. 16.--The West India and Pacific Steam-ship Company's steamer American, Capt. Wallace, which sailed from Aspinwall for Liverpool on Aug. 9, encountered heavy weather when at sea between Savanilla and Carthagena. The ship was struck by lightning, and one of her masts is reported to have been shivered. No loss of life occurred, nor was serious damage done.

Mr. George H. Purser occupied the chair, and Mr. Thomas Costigan acted as Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--Mention was made in yesterday's TIMES of the sudden appearance in this city of Frank Dixon, the brother of the Yazoo victim, and the reasons for his hasty flight from Mississippi. On arriving here he found his mother and sisters greatly grieved, and that only added to the nervousness caused by the strain of excitement under which he has lived for several weeks past.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 26.--Col. Tom Buford, the murderer of Judge Elliott, is still in the Louisville Jail, awaiting the time when he will be allowed a new trial or ordered to be sent to the Penitentiary at Frankfort, there to spend the remainder of his life. Buford persistently refuses to be interviewed, and the numerous attempts of reporters to have a conversation with him have proved failures.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 26.--Senator Jones, of Florida, passed through Atlanta on his way to Wytheville, Va., where he will join his family. While here he was asked for his views upon the next Presidential contest.

LONDON, Aug. 26.--The Mark-lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade for the week, says: "The heavy rain-storms of the past week have seriously laid the crops in many parts of the northern and midland counties, while the submersion of the low-lying lands has caused the wheat plant to rot at the root and develop mildew in the ear in large quantities.

The steam-ship Arizona, of the Guion Line, sailed for Liverpool yesterday. She will be followed to-day by three European vessels--the France, of the French Line, for Havre; the Abyssinia, of the Cunard Line, for Liverpool, and the Greece, of the National Line, for London.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 26.--About 10 days ago a call was made by the Democratic committee, calling upon the leading German Democrats of the State to convene here to-day for the purpose of consultation.

VIENNA, Aug. 26.--One of the editors of the Tagblatt has had an interview with Count Andrassy, who stated that his resignation was against the wish of the Emperor, and his Majesty only consented to it because he was unwilling to take the responsibility of retaining him in office to the detriment of his health.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--On application from the Interior Department, Secretaary McCrary has directed that first Lieut. Richard H. Platt, Tenth Cavalry, report to Secretary Schurz for special duty in connection with Indian education.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 26.--There is a small decrease in new cases officially reported to-day, yet the number is still very large--28 new cases, 15 of which are of white persons and 13 colored.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26.--The Railway Committee resumed its investigation at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Mr. Jewett's examination was continued.

CAMP SKILLMAN, N.J., Aug. 26.--Last year, at Deckerstown, an unclouded sky, intolerable heat, suffocating dust, and but scant preparations for comfort; this year, at Skillman's, a pouring rain, deep Jersey mud, and every possible preparation made for their reception.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 26.--A quarrel occurred this morning between Edward Murphy and William Madden, seamen on the United States surveying schooner Eagle, at Newport, resulting in the serious stabbing of Madden by Murphy, who was arrested.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 26.--This season's grape crop along the Hudson River will be the largest ever shipped. The vines are in vigorous condition, and the fruit is large in size. In a few places the vines have suffered from the ravages of the phylloxera, but that is the exception not the rule.

All reports agree remarkably as to the prospects of a decisive Republican victory in Maine next month, to be followed by one even more important in Ohio in October. In both States the situation has much in common. In both the doubtful element is the strength of the Greenback...

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27.--The open-to-all amateur rowing regatta, under the auspices of the Detroit River Navy, commenced this afternoon in the presence of 5,000 people, who crowded the grand stand and excursion steamers.

It was just about dusk last evening when a TIMES reporter arrived at Graystone, the Summer residence of ex-Gov. Tilden, near Yonkers, and the Governor was just returning to the mansion with some guests after a stroll about the grounds and down the terraced hills toward the river.
CHICAGO, Aug 27.--Howard, White, Crowell , publishers of the Daily Commercial Bulletin, issued their annual estimate of the Spring wheat crop of the North-west to-day.

Washington, Aug. 27.--Upon the return to this city of Senator Bruce, who is now in Cleveland, the committee of which he is Chairman will probably adopt new plans of proceeding with the investigation of the affairs of the Freedman's Savings Bank.

Edward Payson Weston, the last winner of the Astley belt, and champion pedestrain of the world, arrived in this City in the steam-ship Nevada yesterday, accompanied by his wife, three children, and a valet.
UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 27.--There are many indications pointing to the fact that the success of resumption has done much to weaken the Greenback-Labor Party in this State.
Max Strakosch arrived in this City, on the steam-strip Bothnia, yesterday. He told a TIMES reporter some of his plans for the ensuing season.

John Kelly has issued another manifesto against Gov. Robinson, protesting against the latter's renomination for the office he now holds, and insisting that the Democrats belonging to Tammany Hall will never lend their support to such a renomination.

Those who anticipated a lively time at the head-quarters of the Park Commission yesterday were disappointed. No meeting of the board was held, nor will there be a meeting before next Wednesday, unless a necessity arises for issuing a special call for one at an earlier date.

The steam tug-boat Essex formerly belonged to the Central Railroad of New-Jersey; but when the property of that corporation passed into the hands of a Receiver, the Essex and her sister boat, the Clifton, became the property of the New-Jersey Dock and Improvement Company.

CAMP SKILLMAN, N.J., Aug. 27.--Bright skies and perfect weather greeted the inmates of this encampment this morning, and the boys, awakened by the reveille, rejoiced accordingly, and prepared for a day of pleasure.

The decision of Judge Van Vorst, published yesterday, holding that street obstructions and incumbrances, even though authorized by the Board of Aldermen, are illegal, was received with amazement and alarm by the keepers of sidewalk booths in the neighborhood of Washington Market, and by others whose business is carried on in defiance of the right of the public to free and clear thoroughfares.

The Gramercy Boat Club had its tenth annual regatta yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River. The members took out their friends on board the little High Bridge steamer Tiger Lily, which followed the several races.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--The commission of experts appointed by the National Board of Health to prepare a circular embodying familiar instructions for disinfection have made a report to the board.

Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD is still full of fiery indignation against Mr. SAMUEL J. TILDEN. It is now nearly three weeks since the anger of Mr. FIELD was publicly kindled, but the soft answers of Mr. TILDEN have failed to turn away his wrath.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 27.--It will be recollected that a few days ago a dispatch from Kansas City stated that William K. Bell, Receiving Clerk in the American and Kansas Pacific Express office, in that city, had fled with a large sum of money.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1.--The Washipshan missionary case, which for the past year has attracted much attention, has been finally decided by the British court at Shanghai. The missionaries complained of an alleged outrage by a mob near Fooshow, declaring that their property was wantonly destroyed and their premises invaded.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27.--For the first time in three years, the American Association for the Advancement of Science meets in a cool place. Nashville and St. Louis, in August proved, as might have been expected, intolerably hot.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 27.--The Greenbackers of Lackawanna County had a stormy convention here to-day, which threatened on several occasions to break into a riot, owing to the fierce rivalry of the Collins and Stanton factions in seeking to secure an indorsement for the judiciary of their respective leaders.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 27.--Gov. Garcelon, the Democratic nominee for Governor, spoke here to-night in the City Hall to about 1,500 people.

UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 27.--The Republican managers of the First District of Oneida County have selected as delegates to the Saratoga Convention, Roscoe Conkling, W. H. Watson, G.W. Chadwick, and Newton Sholes.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 27.--During several days past the number of new cases has been alarming, but to-day's reports are more favorable, and certainly comforting to those here who, besides being work-worn from caring for the sick and providing for the needy, are becoming weary of the monotonous prospect of having to devote their time for two months longer in the same dreary drudgery.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--The North German Gazette publishes intelligence from Vienna that Count Andrassy has proposed Baron Haymerle as his successor, and that, should the Emperor approve of this choice, Herr Kallay will be appointed Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

ROSLYN, Aug. 27.--The Republicans of the First District of Queens County chose three delegates to the Saratoga Convention, at the Pavilion Hotel, to-day. Mr. Isaac H. Cooks called the meeting to order, and the officers chosen were S. B. Caldwell, President, and F. M. Eastman and Joseph Williams, Secretaries.
Creedmoor range was gay with flags and streamers yesterday, presenting a more lively appearance than it has worn since the Autumn meeting last year.
United States Marshal PAYN has thought it necessary to impugn the accuracy of our report of his proceedings at the recent convention in Columbia County.

PARIS, Aug. 13.--Has the subscription to the Panama Canal stock filled? The emission began a week ago, on the 6th, and, as yet, we have not heard how capital has responded to the appeal of the great promoter of interoceanic communications.
Mr. VANDERBILT has lately announced that he will not permit the international walking-match to take place at the Madison-Square Garden.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 28.--The Grand Jury to-day found true bills against four of the seven men arraigned for corrupt solicitation in connection with the Riot Damages bill of last Winter's session of the Legislature.

SARATOTG, Aug. 28.--The great event of the annual gathering of science in midsummer is always the address of the presiding officer of the preceding meeting. The address was delivered as a lecture, this evening, to a large audience in the Town Hall. Prof. Marsh, the "retiring President," presented the "History and Methods of Paleontological Discovery."

A dispatch was printed in a morning paper of this City yesterday, stating that a journalist of Grand Rapids, Mich., had found certain letters extracts from which were published--believed to have been written by the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Thompson, at present residing in Berlin, and which if genuine, seemed to show that improper relations had existed between that gentleman and the journalist's wife, Mrs. Sarah Deland.

Conventions were held in each of the twelve Assembly districts of Kings County last evening to elect delegates to the Assembly Convention. While all of the candidates who have been prominently mentioned for the Governorship have friends among the delegates, the delegation is absolutely unpledged.

SARATOGA, Aug. 28.--On one point all the members of the association who are here agree, that this is one of its best meetings, if not the very best. Only their native modesty prevents them from saying that science was never before so well represented in this country.

QUEBEC, Aug. 28.--In the Legislative Council last night the Hon. Dr. Ross moved a series of resolutions calling upon the Lieutenant Governor to remove his Ministers, and refusing to pass the Supply bill.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The Railroad Committee resumed its investigation this morning, with Mr. Vanderbilt on the stand and Mr. Sterne conducting the examination.

About a week ago Superintendent Smyth, of the Insurance Department, made the announcement through our Albany correspondent of the results of some examinations of fire insurance companies in this City.

Several fatal accidents have recently occurred in this country to persons while in a state of somnambulism. This propensity to sleep-walking is a curious phenomenon and has attracted a good deal of attention from men of science; but, unfortunately, no cure has as yet been discovered for the disease.

The approach of the September term of the Hudson County Court, which opens at the Courthouse, on Jersey City Heights, next Tuesday, renews speculation as to when and where the new trial of Mrs. Smith and Bennett for the murder of Policeman Smith will take place, and as to the Judge before whom it will be conducted.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 28.--The open-to-all amatuer regatta of the Detroit River Navy closed to-day. The mile and a half straight-away race, for four-oared shells, undecided yesterday, was called at 10 A.M.
The first regatta of the Jersey City Canoe Club was contested yesterday afternoon on Communipaw Bay, and proved as successful as it was novel and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--The recommendation of the Academic Board, under paragraph 9 of the Regulations of the United States Military Academy, that the subjects of geology and mineralogy be transferred from the fourth year to the third year of the course of instruction at the Military Academy, has been approved by the Secretary of War.

Crook's Amateur Band gives its last concert for the season at the Battery to-night. Ira D. Sankey is to conduct the singing at Mr. Sawyer's religious meeting in the large hall of Cooper Institute on Sunday evening.

In June last Chief-Justice Waite, of the United States Supreme Court, sat in the United States Circuit Court, in this City, to hear appeals in Admiralty and other cases, and yesterday he forwarded to the Clerk decisions and opinions in several of these cases.
The tenth bi-weekly competition at the Brinton (N.J.) State Range for the championship marksman's badge brought out a fair gathering yesterday.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The Oneida Communists, whose internal dissensions and troubles from external causes have been the occasion of many newspaper articles during the last year, have taken an important step toward reorganization by formally abandoning the system of complex marriage that Father John Humphrey Noyes has consistently advocated for so many years.

Edward Payson Weston, the present champion pedestrian of the world, spent a busy day yesterday. He was in no hurry to rise, however, in the morning, and it was not until quite late that he left his rooms in the Rossmore Hotel and could be seen by his friends.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 28.--The daily reports of the past week have been presenting alarming figures, with no reasonable cause visible upon which to base a hope of the plague's abatement. To-day three new cases are all that the physicians report as coming within the circle of their practice during the past 24 hours.

Michael Gastman, residing at No. 56 Firstavenue, complained to Superintendent Walling, yesterday morning, of Patrolman Daniel J. Egan, of the Nineteenth Precinet Police. One of Gastman's eyes was discolored and partially closed, and his face bore other marks of a severe beating.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 28.--The Russian authorities at Odessa had prepared a grand reception for Mr. Maynard, the United States Minister, and the officers and crew of the United States steamer Wyoming, and ordered that public establishments should not accept any payment for expenses from the Americans. Mr. Maynard, however, was obliged to leave Odessa before the principal fete took place in consequence of a meeting of the diplomatic body in Constantinople.

The domestic difficulties of Capt. Oliver Perry Hazzard, the details of which have been unfolded in Police courts at various times, came up yesterday, in two courts. Hazzard formerly commanded a steamer of the Savannah Line, and was, at one time, a prominent naval officer.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 28.--Nine weeks ago last Monday, Patrick Smith, an aged and respectable lrish resident of this city, disappeared from his home. He had been a sufferer from malarial fever, which left him half demented, and during his convalescence he took a notion that his family did not want him around the house any longer, as he was unable to work, and would have to be supported during the remainder of his days.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--If any evidence he needed to prove that the Greenback-Labor Party of New-York is thoroughly in earnest, it may be found in the fact that the State Convention of that organization, now in session at Utica, has spent the entire day in discussing nice points of order, which were neither appreciated nor understood by the handful of outside spectators present.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 25.--The political contest which has been waging for nearly five weeks in this State is fast drawing to a close.

VINELAND, N.J., Aug. 27.--The first ship ment of Concord grapes was made from Vineland on Monday. Six years ago this variety of fruit was the great staple crop of this section, and it was thought by growers that an abundant yield could be predicted with absolute certainty each season.

SERRA, in the pitoian Apennines, Aug. 16.--I am summering in an Apennine perch, 30 miles north-west of Florence as the crow flies. From it can be seen its giant dome, many-colored campanile, and ancient towers glittering in the clear sunlight, with the soft outlines of the Vallambrosa Range looming high and broad in the background, bounding the horizon as many more miles away.

Mr. ALONZO B. CORNELL, the nominee of the convention for Governor, is a son of the Hon. Ezra Cornell, the founder of Cornell University. He was born at Ithaca, Jan. 22, 1832, and received his early education at the academy in that town. At the age of 15 he was at work, earning his own living.

LONDON, Sept. 6.--Wilbur F. Raymond, the defaulting agent of Rumsey Co., of Seneca Falls, N.Y., who was arrested here, recently, on a charge of forgery, but released from custody in consequence of a telegram from his employers, who declined to prosecute the case, died at his hotel of dropsy of the heart.

Christian has been notorious for years as a keeper of houses of prostitution.

James Murphy fell from a freight car in the Erie Railway yard, Jersey City, Monday night, and was fatally injured. On his return from the East, Gen. Grant is to visit tha residence of Mr. Corbin, in Jersey City, where his mother is stopping.

The steam-ship P. Caland, which arrived from Rotterdam yesterday, had on board Capt. L. C. Larsen and the entire crew of a Norwegian bark which was lost in mid-ocean under remarkable circumstances. Capt. Larsen's story, which is fully corroborated by his men, goes to show that the accounts which have been given to the public from time to time of dangerous sea monsters inhabiting the ocean are not wholly false.

ST. Louis, Mo., Sept. 9.--There is good reason to believe that private meetings of railroad men have been held here and in New-York since the consolidation of the Wabash and the St. Louis, Kansas City, and Northern Roads, with a view to providing another through line to the Pacific coast, in opposition to Jay Gould's scheme.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 9.--Better weather for racing could not have been desired than that which attended the second day of the Fall meeting of the Kentucky Association. The track was not in the best condition, being somewhat slow, but it was good enough to afford fine sport. The attendance was very good and the pool-selling spirited. There were three races on the programme.

The residence of D. Ogden Bradley, at Dobb's Ferry, was entered by burglars last Monday evening. His house is furnished throughout with burglar alarms on the doors and windows, but they are not usually set until about 10 P.M., when the members of the family retire.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9.--The British steam-ship Farnley returned to this port this morning. Her machinery is disabled and her bulwarks are stove. She was in collision with the three-masted schooner A.R. Weeks, hence on Sept. 8, for Boston, laden with coal. The schooner sank with all sails standing. Her crew was taken on board the Farnley and brought to this city.

The town of Hastings, as the geographers prove, is situated on the Hudson River, and its inhabitants, in order to distinguish it from Hastings on the British Channel, have agreed to call it Hastings-on-Hudson.

BUFFALO, Sept. 15. As was anticipated, the agreement made by the officers interested in the telegraph war between the Western Union and American Union Companies, on Saturday afternoon, while they were under arrest in the Police Court, was not adhered to, though the renewal of hostilities did not occur for 24 hours later than was expected.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15. The Stock Boards have decided to adjourn for the day when the arrival of Gen. Grant is telegraphed. Should a session be in progress at the time, it will be completed.

The investigation of the charges brought by the Bar Association against Sheriff Bernard Reilly was resumed yesterday before Referee Curtis, in the General Term room of the Supreme Court. CHICAGO, Sept. 15. Jay Gould spent the afternoon and evening here yesterday consulting with officers connected with railroad lines under his control.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23.--An interesting compilation of statistics bearing upon the homicidal tendencies of the people of Kentucky will be published to-morrow. It represents thorough investigations among the records of 20 counties, taken at random, of the State. The work occupied a special correspondent three months. The figures are entirely accurate.

On Monday night, A.T. Lobdell's store, at Brewsters, Putnam County, was entered by burglars. In his store are the village a Post Office and the Putnam County Savings Bank. WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--Ordnance-Sergeant Adelplh Dagenfield is relieved from duty at Fort Clark, Texas, and transferred to Columbus Barracks, Ohio, relieving Ordnance-Sergeant Wm. J. Russell, who is ordered to duty at Fort Clark, Texas.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept 29.--Notwithstanding the increased vigilance of the revenue officers, illicit distillation is constantly going on, and frauds in the manufacture and sale of tobacco are detected every dap. The broken country, with its hills and mount.

HARTFORD, Sept. 29.--An important divorce case is to come up for trial in this city, to-morrow, before the Superior Court, and will attract more attention probably in this part of the State than any other similar case for many years, because of the position of the parties.

Jacob Schaefer, holder of the Brunswick emblem of the billiard championship of the world, and George F. Slosson, the noted billiard-player, signed the articles of agreement for their coming match yesterday at the Union-Square Rooms.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 29.--F. Prentice is one of the most widely-known oil operators in the Pennsylvania oil regions. He built the first pipeline in the Bradford region. He made a large fortune...

PARIS, Sept. 29.--The Hon. Fernando Wood, of New-York, and M. Leon Chotteau, after spending a few days with Daniel Wilson, the reporter of the Budget Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, at his seat in Indre-et-Loire, have gone to Bordeaux.

"A Grand Inauguration of Annual Athletic Games" was the title of an entertainment given at Madison-Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening--which was like a farce following the serious business of the international walking match.

The examination in the case of Albert Kraemer, who was charged by Mrs. Mary Moore with conducting a mock auction at No. 131 West Fourteenthstreet, was resumed Yesterday before Col. John Tracy, the Mayor's chief clerk.

LONDON, Sept. 29.--The mass-meeting summoned to assemble on Saturday, in Hyde Park, to denounce the incapacity of the Government, and to demand an appeal to the country, proved to be a failure. The attendance was meagre and no prominent leaders were present.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29.--The United States Circuit Court, which was in session to-day, Judges Mckennan and Nixon on the bench, was engaged in hearing an argument in a very peculiar case, which is said to be without precedent--an application for an injunction against the financial officers of the City of Elizabeth and for the appointment of a Receiver. The suit is that of Peter Goelet and others...

The effort made by Tammany Hall to induce the courts to direct the Board of Police Commissioners to appoint as Inspectors of Election for the Democratic Party the persons proposed for appointment by that local organization has failed.

The arguments were closed, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on the question whether the body of Denis Coppers shall be buried in the plot in Calvary Cemetery which he bought in 1873, or shall be excluded from consecrated ground because he was a Freemason.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29.--At the invitation of the Marine Reception Committee, Gen. Grant and a number of guests breakfasted at the Cliff House this morning.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 29.--Just beyond the Moosic Mountains, a few miles north-east of this city, in the primitive village of Salem, there lives a centenarian whose history reads like a page plucked from one of the Leather-stocking romances. Abraham Johnson is now 106 years old--hale, hearty, unimpaired in intellect, and gifted with a remarkable memory. His family record shows that he was born...
LONDON, Sept. 30.--A Vienna dispatch says: "The Emperor of Russia is suffering from mental fatigue and is daily getting worse."

The work of the Republican State Committee in organizing and preparing for the coming canvass is being pushed forward with great rapidity and thoroughness. The progress already made is highly satisfactory. As was announced in THE TIMES on Monday last, invitations to take part in the campaign have been extended to Secretaries Sherman, Evarts, and Schurz.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--A Coroner's inquest in the case of Mark Jenks, who was terribly outraged at West Stephentown recently, was held yesterday, and Stephen Sweet was declared guilty of the crime. He has been arrested, and is now in the Troy Jail.

The Guion steam-ship Arizona sailed for Liverpool yesterday. Scholten, of the NetherlandsAmerican Line, for Rotterdam. Three steam-ships will go on Thursday, and six more will follow on Saturday. The following lists have been received:

A good deal is being made, not only in this State, but in others, in the pending political canvass of what is called "the ruinous competition of convict labor with honest industry."
STOCKTON, Cal., Sept. 30.--Gen. Grant and party left Oakland Wharf at 8:30 o'clock this morning. On the landing was a dense mass of people, and as the train moved off three cheers were given.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 30.--The adjourned meeting of the National Military Convention met at Armory Hall at noon to-day, and was called to order by Gen. W.C. Squires, of St. Louis. A letter was read from Gen. E.H. Barney, President of the convention, expressing regret that he could not be present.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--A Paris correspondent says: "The Journal des Debats states that the Foreign Office is considering the expediency of creating French chambers of commerce abroad, and giving the most important French consulates the assistance of commercial agents."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30.--The races at the Jockey Club Course went on to-day, although a rather poor crowd was present, Gen. Buford did not allow Good Night to run against time. The first event of the day was a three-quarter-mile dash, with Glendalia, Buckshot, and Judge Thompson as contestants. Glendalia was the favorite.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The "bulls" and "bears" on Change were wrought up with excitement at an unusually early hour this morning. Late yesterday afternoon the former kept the prices of November No. 2 up to $1.08 , but this morning, at the call board, the " bears" turued out in great force.

Police Commissioners MacLean, French, Morrison, and Wheeler met in the board-room, at Police Head-quarters, at noon yesterday, to endeavor to comply with the law which required them to appoint Inspectors of Election before Oct. 1. The Republican Commissioners were advised by Mr. Elihu Root, and Col. John R. Fellows seemed to act as counsel for Mr. Morrison.

The Mercantile Mutual Marine Insurance Company, of No. 35 Wall-street, is about to wind up its business. The process of closing up its affairs has been going on for at least three months, and has... been voluntary on the part of the Directors.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--The Times, in a leading editorial on the discouraging effects of Mr. Parnell's policy, says it would become really formidable only if it should extend all over Ireland. The Times does not believe that it will do so. Nothing, it says, will tend to paralyze the anti-rent projects more effectually than the improvement in the harvest prospects, which is reported from the greater part of Ireland.
Every now and then the cable brings us a fragment of news about complications in the distant East which have little significance for the general reader, because its bearings are not understood.

Justice Frederick W. Ricord, of Netwark, before whom the Rev. Father McCarthy, of St. Plus's Church, East Newark, was arraigned on a charge of drunkenness, Monday evening, has preferred charges against Officer Knapp, who, with Officer Glovi, made the arrest.
The Greenbackers of Erie County have nominated Francis U. Coe for State Senator. The Albany Express believes that the Republicans would carry the Stats even if the Democrats were united.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30.--The wound given Col. M. Lewis Clark, President of the Louisville Jockey Club, at the Galt House, last night, is more painful than at first supposed. His assailant, Capt. Moore, was presented before the court today, and held in $1,200 to answer on Nov. 8. He gave bail, and was released. The feeling here is very strong against Moore, especially as his best friends counseled him against his action.

Intense excitement was caused a few minutes before 1 P.M. yesterday among the stall-keepers and customers in Clinton Market by the attempted murder of Henry Von Gerichten, a butcher, by John Sheehan, a sign-painter, who, after firing two shots at the butcher, sent one bullet with fatal effect throught his own brain.

The Pilot Commissioners met yesterday. Mr. William Allen Butler, counsel to the board, to whom was referred the complaint of the residents of Tottenville against the Atlantic Dredging Company, that it is dredging mud at Perth Amboy, N.J., and depositing it in the Staten Island side of the channel, reported that the Commissioners have no jurisdiction, and the complainants were advised to apply to the Attorney-General of the State for relief.

Secretary Evarts arrived in the City last evening from Washington. Discharges in bankruptcy were granted yesterday in the United States District Court, by Judge Choate, to Elias Ponvert, Jr., and Louis J. Ponvert.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The two colored men who recently arrived here as agents of the colored people of the Second Congressional District of North Carolina, and whose statements of the hardships that prompt the colored people to emigrate were published in THE TIMES, called to-day at THE TIMES'S Washington office to say that their published statements have somewhat stirred up the white people in their section of the country.

A gentleman, whose active friendship for "President" Tilden in 1876-7-8, during the election, the electoral count, and, subsequently, during the Potter investigation, earned for him a national reputation as a competent Democratic manager, arrived in Washington yesterday from NewYork, where he has recently had several interviews with the Gramerey Park statesman.

"Bring me a dictionary," said JOHN RANDOLPH of Roanoke, on his death-bed. They brought him a copy of Webster's Unabridged Dictionary--the edition of 1876, full of diagrams of pleasing and improving animals.
There is nothing improbable in the exhibit of Mr. TILDEN'S ideas in regard to national affairs, which a Washington journal professess to have derived from one of his intimate friends.

About 3,000 persons, many of whom were ladies, attended at Madison Square Garden last night to witness the presentation of the Astley belt to Charles Rowell. An elaborate programme of music and pedestrianism had been prepared, but owing to various unforeseen circumstances, its most important features were not carried out.
Miss Agnes Ethel sailed for Europe last week, "The Danites" will be produced in London next May. All the Chicago theatres now remain open on Sunday evenings.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 30.--In the Court of Appeals, to-day, the following decisions were handed down: Heermans vs. Burt; Gelston vs. Shields; Miller vs. Montgomery; Feldman vs. Beir; Quick vs. Wheeler; Willy vs Mulledy--Judgment affirmed, with costs.

The all-day meeting conducted by Mr. Moody and Mr. Sankey, with the assistance of Mr. Sawyer, in Cooper Union Hall yesterday, was attended by a great many of the professing Christians of this City. The morning meeting was advertised to continue from 9 to 10.

The first of the season of orchestral concerts will take place at Steinway Hall on Monday evening next, the 6th inst., when Mr. Theodore Thomas (who, by the way, is now in New-York,) will be the conductor.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept 30.--The English Parliamentary Commission to investigate the causes of agricultural depression have been traveling through Minnesota and Dakota for several days past. They have gone over most of the important lines of railroad in the northern part of...
The Fall opening at Arnold, Constable Co.'s, Broadway and Nineteenth-street, occurred yesterday. There was a line of carriages in Nineteenth-street from morning until night.

Mr. Daly's well-known play, "Divorce," was revived last evening under pleasant circumstances, and was received with a good deal of favor. There are probably few threatre goers in this City who are not acquainted with "Divorce," so that our notice of it need be only cursory.

Not many weeks ago the population of the Neighborhood of Tompkins-square assembled in that place to the number of many thousands to celebrate the completion of the work which was to turn it from a gravel desert into a pretty park.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept, 30.--A hearing of the creditors of the Rev. W.H.H. Murray, on the appointment of a Trustee, was held before Probate Judge Landon, at Guilford, today. About 15 creditors were present, or were represented by lawyers, the aggregate amount of their claims being about $15,000.
Mrs. Josephine Jurgessen, a highly-respectable lady, a native of France, 49 years of age, was brought before Justice Flammer, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with insanity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--An interesting decision has just been rendered by Acting Secretary Bell, of the Interior Department, in the case of Hugh Lyons against Rachel Stevens, of Salt Lake City, involving a question of the right of these parties to a section of land in the Salt Lake City land district.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 30.--On Sunday last, as mentioned in to-day's TIMES, Mrs. Laney Barnard, a widow, 61 years of age, died in the village of Chittenango, 15 miles east of Syracuse. Her death was attended with great agony, and suspicion was aroused that she had been poisoned.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 30.--Three new cases were reported up to 10 A.M.--Sister Agnes and two colored. The undertakers report three interments--Mary Bacon, Mrs. Martha Milburn, and L. Winston. Up to noon seven more cases were reported--Susie Lucas, James Rice, Adolph Rosedale, Mrs. Mary Bacon, (died last night,) Annie and Leo Werne. and Sallie White, the last-named colored.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday at noon, at which time the chamber was crowded with politicians. Immediately after President Mott had taken the chair, Col. Tracey, the Mayor's chief clerk, entered the room and handed the President a number of official communications.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The carting and stacking of wheat and barley during the past week were somewhat delayed by intermitteut showers.

A very remarkable case, which has for two years past been before the civil courts in a variety of phases, made its appearance yesterday in a new shape at the Jefferson Market Police Court, when Mr. Andrew D. Purtell, than whom no person is better known in the Washington Market and vicinity, was arraigned before Justice Flammer, charged with false pretenses.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 30.--The Ingalls investigation was continued to-day. John Bissell, member from Phillips County, testified that Ingalls had offered him control of the patronage in his county if he would remove the prejudices existing there against him, and vote for him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The total receipts of internal revenue for the first quarter of the current fiscal year were $29,405,894, which is an increase of $170,192 over the receipts for the corresponding period of last year.

Sanitary Inspector Roger S. Tracy, M.D., line transmitted to Sanitary Superintendent Day a long report of an examination of the condition of the water-front of this City, made recentry Dr. Elisha Harris, Inspector Nealls, and himself. The report was presented to the Board of Health at its meeting yesterday, and ordered on file.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 30.--The Greenfield trial was resumed this morning. On the opening of the court, the father, mother, and uncle of the prisoner entered the room and took their seats beside him.

The medical department of the University, which during the past Summer has been redecorated and tastefully frescoed, was the scene last evening of a brilliant gathering of students and their lady friends, drawn together to listen to the introductory lecture of the Winter session.

Maria Dichico Balbo, the young wife of an Italian named Pedro Balbo, was found dead in bed in their miserable home at No. 14 Rose-street yesterday, her throat cut, stab-wounds in both sides of her neck, and one of her hands lacerated.

The question as to the advisability of retaining Mr. Henry Kiddle in the position of City Superintendent of Schools was finally decided in the negative by the Board of Education yesterday, and Mr. John Jasper, Jr., an Assistant City Superintendent, was chosen as his successor.

Of the many Fall openings which denote the revival and progress of trade, and which command the attention of lady customers, that of Loeser Co., of Brooklyn, may be fairly set down among the most important.

The Rev. Dr. LODGE, a Baptist minister, of Jersey City, has recently been made the object of a good deal of severe criticism.

The session of the Board of Police Commissioners, which began at noon on Tuesday, did not come to an end until 3:15 P.M. yesterday, and when the board adjourned but six Inspectors of Election representing the Tammany Hall Democracy had been appointed.

Although the Mr. GARRETT, of Baltimore, who writes of "The Railway Problem" in the North American Review, is not the President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the article leaves little doubt as to the source of its inspiration or the authority that gives weight to its opinions.

The Cunard steamer Bothnia, after lying at Quarantine Tuesday night, came up to her dock early yesterday morning to land her passengers. She brought many returning Summer tourists, and there was quite a crowd of friends and relatives to meet them.
BERLIN, Oct. 1. Mr. Charles F. Macdonald, Superintendent of the United States moneyorder system, has arrived here to negotiate a new postal money-order treaty.
The Union and Middlesex Counties Agricultural Associations will hold their joint fair on the grounds at Plainfield, commencing on Monday next.
Judson Beeman, who says he is a farmer and horse-dealer of Essex County, near Windsor, Canada, came to this City on Tuesday.
Mr. Charles Reade has written the following letter to the Mancester Examiner in reply to some reflections upon him:
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. The annual Fall regatta of the Yale University Boat Club took place at Lake Saltonstall this afternoon. The attendance was fair.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The death of Mr. John W. Hill, the artist, which took place last week at his home, near Nyackon-the-Hudson, is an occurrence which justifies more than passing notice.
From 2 A.M. until 3:15 P.M. yesterday, when the Board of Police Commissioners adjourned, only six Inspectors of Election were appointed, and these were given to Tammany.

Among the historic questions destined to remain unanswered is obviouly this: Who reduced the City laborers' wages from $2 to $1.60? Mr. JOHN KELLY is responsible for the revival of this political ghost.
The New-York Woman Suffrage Society will hold a meeting this evening at No. 103 West Fortyeighth-street.
Philadelphia's first Chinese resident to be naturalized is Adamanto Lenen, who was made a citizen on Friday last.
The Faculty of Columbia College Law School were busy yesterday in attending to the registration of the large number of young men who are to attend the lectures this Winter.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 1. The reunion of surviving Union prisoners of the late rebellion has developed a most unexpected interest and an unlooked-for attendance.

LONDON, Oct. 1. The Financier of to-day says: "As exchange on New-York has again sunk to the bullion point, it is expected that the 150,000 remaining on the market from the Australian consignment of 200,000, mentioned on Saturday, will go to America.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 1. The Mahoning Presbytery is now in session in this city for the purpose of investigating charges of immorality against the Rev. W.J. Park, Pastor of the Presbyterian church.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. A, large number of politicians and business men, Republicans and Democrats, once-holders and non-office-holders, have been questioned about the chief political sensation of the day the approach of Gen. Grant and the prospects of his nomination for the Presidency next year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1. The prosecution in the Greenfield case closed to-day, an extra session of the court having been held this evening in order that the testimony of the last witness for the people might be taken.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 1. Mrs. Mary Antoinette Simmons was the wife of Duane B. Simmons, a prominent physician of Yokohoma, Japan.
DUBLIN, Sept. 20. In the multiplicity of special correspondents there is an embarrassing variety of opinion as to what really is the condition of the country this Autumn.

The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Peabody Education Fund took place at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. The Hon. Robert C. Winthrop, of Massachusetts, presided. The other members present were Gen. Barnes, of Washington;...

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 1. The Senate committee in the Ingalls investigation decided today that the allegation of packing the Grand Jury in the memorial was not proper evidence of corruption, in that it was anterior to the election and could not affect it.
Sir Bache Cunard and Mr. Charles G. Francklyn, the New-York agent of the Cunard Line, and his family were among the passengers of the steam-ship Abyssinia, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday.
NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 1. For some time the project of admitting Yale Alumni to a sharp in the management of the athletic sports of the college has been discussed.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1. A grand Republican ratification meeting, the opening event of the campaign in this State, was held, this evening, at Concordia Opera-house, in this city.

The fourth of the series of concerts by Mme. Carlotta Patti and Messrs. Ketten, De Munek, Phelps, and Ciampi-Cellaj at Chickering Hall, last evening, attracted a numerous and brilliant audience despite the weather and the many attractions at other places of entertainment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. Gen. Crook has sent to Lieut-Gen. Sheridan the following dispatch, received by him from Assistant Adjt. Gen. R. Williams, at Omaha. It is dated at Milk River, Col., Sept. 29, at 8:30 P.M.:

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club will begin to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 1. The National Militia Convention met again this morning. The committee appointed at the New-York meeting last Winter to frame the constitution and by-laws reported, and their work was accepted and adopted.
HARTFORD, Oct. 1. The Rev. J.B.R. Walker filed this morning his answer to the allegations made by his wife, Mary S. Walker, which were published in full in THE TIMES OF Tuesday.

Senator WALLACE resorts to an old device in the interest of his Southern allies. Before the war we were continually told that "cotton is king," and should be master in politics as well as in commerce.
Mayor Cooper took measures last evening to break the dead-lock in the Police Board which has prevented the appointment of a full list of Poll Clerks and Inspectors of Election.

Among the rules laid down by President HAYES for the conduct of the civil service is one which formed a prominent feature in the scheme of reform submitted in 1872, and which forbade the levying of what are called political assessments upon the employes of the Government.

BERLIN, Oct. 2.--At Leipsie yesterday Herr Friedberg, the Secretary of State, opened the Imperial Supreme Court and administered the oaths to Dr. Simson, the President, and the other officers. The judiciary reforms decreed by the Reichstag throughout the Empire also went into operation yesterday.
The arguments in favor of the establishment of an International Park at Niagara Falls seem to be as numerous and, at least, quite as worthy of consideration as are those against the project.
The new hall and library of the New-York Academy of Medicine, at No. 12 West Thirty-fourthstreet, was dedicated and formally opened last evening.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 2.--Gov. Pitkin, of Colorado, a short time ago received a letter from Agent Meeker, of which the following is a copy:

The National steam-ship Erin, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, brought Mr. Lorillard's celebrated horses. Duke of Magenta and Uncas. It was thought unwise by many when the stud to which these two animals belonged sailed last Fall to send them out so late in the season.

Anthony Krunich, of Charlotte County, Va., after abusing his father-in-law, Mr. Thomas O. Woodruff, in front of the latter's house, in West Orange, N.J., on Wednesday evening, fired three shots at him, wounding him in the head, and then put the pistol to his own temple and fired, killing himself instantly.

An extra room in the St. James Hotel, adjoining those which have been set aside for the use of the Democratic State Committee, was yesterday filled with Democrats, candidates as well as men who are not in nomination for office, who had met pursuant to invitation to talk over the work which they have to do before November.

Mr. J. Adriance Bush, counsel for the prosecution in the investigation of the charges brought by the Bar Association against Sheriff Reilly, delivered his summing up yesterday before Referee Curtis, in Part II, of the Supreme Court.

LONDON, Oct. 2.--A correspondent of the Frankfurter Zeitung says: "The addition of four steamers to the Hamburg-American fleet is a practical declaration of war against the freight line projected by a new association of Hamburg capitalists to compete for business with the United States and the West Indies, an enterprise for which two new steamers are already ordered.

The Emperor William completed his eightysecond year last March, and is still strong enough to enjoy a good dinner, though he has an interview every morning with his physician, who decides whether his Majesty is fit to go out, or whether he must keep to his rooms.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The sub-committee appointed by the Railroad Investigating Committee, consisting of Messrs. Hepburn. Dugind Noyes, and Terry, to hear the charges against the Black River Railroad, met here this afternoon.
A second mortgage, amounting to $500,000, on the Brooklyn, Flatbush and Coney Island Railroad, and made in favor of the Brooklyn Trust Company, was filed in the Register's Office yesterday.
Mr. Elihu Root applied to Judge Barrett, yesterday, for a writ of prohibition to prevent Mayor Cooper from taking steps to remove from office Police Commissioner Stephen B. French.

OMAHA, Oct. 2.--The Republican State Convention assembled at the Masonic Hall last night, and was called to order by the Hon. James A. Davis, Chairman of the State Central Committee. The hall was densely crowded.

NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 2.--Norwich was thrown into a state of great excitement to-day by the news that William B. Riddle had been arrested on a charge of poisoning his wife.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 2.--Several serious fires occurred in Minnesota, yesterday, in town and country, causing heavy losses.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 11.--The Republicans opened the campaign in this city to-night by a large ratification meeting in the Academy of Music. J.C. Churchill presided, and addresses were made by the Chairman, Hamilton Ward, and George B. Sloan.

George William Curtis's name was on the lips of nearly every man in a crowd of some 50 or 60 Republicans who gathered in Stapleton, Staten Island, yesterday afternoon, to attend the Richmond County Convention. Mr. Curtis was not in the throng.

Bowery Savings Bank vs. Drake.--It does not appear that Mullen assumed the payment of the mortgage, nor that said mortgage was a part of the consideration of the transfer to him. This does not appear in all the cases.

The hanging on last Thursday of McMANUS, one of the Mollie Maguires who murdered Coroner HESSER five years ago, marks the end of a story of crime which is at once unique in fact and strange beyond the inventions of fiction.

The question is often asked, why have the blue jays forsaken the woods, and made their home anyone the trees in our gardens and pleasure-grounds? For several Summers past these birds have increased in numbers in the very centre of our villages.

MUSCOGEE, Indian Territory, Oct. 4.-- The prevailing idea about the Indian Territory seems to be that it is the garden spot of the United States, that it has immense capacity for producing various agricultural crops, and that every acre may be made to yield profitable return by the labor of the husbandman.

PORT JERVIS, Oct. 10.--When the Erie Company commenced preparations to lay a third rail, plans were drawn by the Chief Engineer, Octave Chanute, for a large class of locomotives, which would be narrow gauge, weighing 52 tons, and with eight wheels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The Secretary of the Navy will leave Washington to-morrow, in the United States steamer Tallapoosa, for Hampton Roads, and will inspect the ships which are ordered to that place on Tuesday.

BOSTON, Oct. 4.--Edgar Parker is the most industrious and most persevering artist in the country. He is finishing a portrait of John G. Whittier which is remarkably life-like. This is copied on a larger canvas from a fine picture painted four years ago, when the poet was in feeble health.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 22.--An accident occurred on the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad at about 11 o'clock last night, near the Bridgewater station, in which a freight train was badly wrecked, 12 cars being thrown from the track. G.C. Lemmon, a brakeman, was instantly killed, and George Fulton, fireman, and H.L. Norr, engineer, were painfully, but not seriously, injured.

Lincoln, who said that the laws bearing on the discharge of seamen in foreign ports must be removed, and that sailing ships engaged in foreign trade must be allowed to take out stores in bond; also that it would be well to remove import duties on ship-building materials.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22.--The Presbyterian Synod of New-York continued its session last night and to-day. The attendance has increased to about 150 ministers and 50 Elders.

The firm of Simpson, Crawford Simpson, the successors of Richard Meares Co., threw open their establishment at Sixth-avenue, corner of Nineteenth-street, to the inspection of their patrons and the public generally yesterday, and a throng of people attended the opening.

The affairs of Feist, Frank Co., wholesale dry goods dealers in San Francisco, present a very poor exhibit for the New-York creditors. Mr. Marvin T. Wood, of Wood Co., who was sent to San Francisco by the New-York creditors to investigate, has returned, and submitted his report to the creditors.

WINNEMUCCA, Nev., Oct. 30.--Gen. Grant arrived here at 10:30 last night, in a special train. When the train stopped, it was immediately surrounded by a large crowd. PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30.--The little City of Parker, on the Allegheny River, 82 miles from here, was almost entirely destroyed to-day by fire. The city lies on both sides of the river, but the finest buildings and the business portion of the place is on a narrow bottom on the north side of the river, and at the foot of a steep bluff, on which are built the residences of the wealthy citizens.

The rival associations claiming the right to control the Protestant Episcopal institution known as the Shepherd's Fold held separate annual meetings yesterday, and each elected a board of officers.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 3.--After a long examination, Wesley R. White, a young married man, living three miles out of the city, has been held for the murder of Miss Lillian Manchester, 17 years old, who died suddenly in this city on the evening of Oct. 10.

On St. Paul's-avenue, Jersey City, is railroad trestle work 75 feet high. Otto Carman, 40 years of age, was employed on it Sunday night. He missed his footing and fell headlong to the ground. DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 3.--The arrangements for the funeral of the late Senator Chandler have not yet been completed, but them is no doubt it will be the most imposing and solemn occasion ever witnessed in this city.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Nov. 3.--The special train sent from Chicago by the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, with Col. and Mrs. F.D. Grant and Capt. J.G. Walker, Secretary of the road, arrived at Council Bluffs early yesterday morning.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 3.--The Globe-Democrat has a special from Joplin, Mo., giving the particulars of the killing of Jesse James, the notorious outlaw, who originated train-robbing, and has been the leader of the most desperate gang of desperadoes ever known in America. SOMMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 18. The Committee for the Investigation of the Affairs of Somerset County has discovered that other papers besides the vouchers, and another important book, besides the two ledgers, belonging to the county, have been stolen. It was supposed that only the documents ...
NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 18. The Jackson murder trial was resumed this morning. Detective Odell was examined at length in regard to his discoveries in the cellar and about the premises.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. United States Treasurer Gilfillan, in submitting his annual report to Secretary Sherman, speaks of the fiscal year ended ...
Assemblyman-elect D. W. Tallmadge has been appointed a temporary clerk in the Tax Office, and will serve in that capacity until the Legislature meets.
The disturbance which is agitating the people of Maine ought to convince them of the expediency of a change in their State Constitution.

As last week, at Chicago, the Society of the Army of the Tennessee turned its annual meeting chiefly into a welcome of Gen. GRANT, so this week, at Washington, the Society of the Army of the Cumberland has made its main business a tribute to the memory of Gen. GEORGE H. THOMAS.
LIVERPOOL,Nov. 19.-It is reported that Mr. Parnell, the Home Rule leader, will abandon his proposed visit to America.

Mlle. Marie Marimon, the gifted artist who has been secured by Col. Mapleson, is rapidly approaching these shores, and it is but natural that some inquiries should be heard as to who Marimon is. whence she comes, and what she has done to awaken so much curiosity at her coming.

The games of the "new champion's game" tournament were resumed last evening in Tammany Hall, and were the medium of introducing Mr. "Yank" Adams in his official position of referee, he having sufficiently recovered from his indisposition to assume the post. The contestants of the evening were Champion Schaefer and Randolph Heiser, and Eugene Carter and Albert Garnier.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 19.-George Trust, who wantonly and without provocation shot and killed the colored man, William A. Robinson, last Tuesday, in Light-street, was arraigned to-day, in the Criminal Court, on an indictment charging him with willful murder, and pleaded not guilty. The trial was set for Dec. 1. United States Senator William Pinckney Whyte is one of his counsel.

An adjourned meeting of the stockholders of the First National Bank, of Hackensack, N. J., of which Congressman Charles H. Voorhis was President, was held yesterday at the bank, when Director De Groot, Chairman of the former meeting, and Cashier John Swinburne, of the First National Bank, of Paterson, made a full report of an examintion which they have been making during the past week.

The thirteenth annual convention of the American Institute of Architects began yesterday, the session being held, through the courtesy of the President and officers of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, in the Directors' room of their building.

The statements made by our correspondent in New-Orleans regarding the manner in which the Government of that city and that of the State have been administered by the Democratic Party are of more than local interest.

Williams, who was named as alternate. He then spoke feelingly of the death of Gen. Hooker, and with the ...

A meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday afternoon, the Hon. William Wood, President in the chair. The report of the Superintendent of Schools, which was received and placed on the stated that the total number of pupils registered in the day schools Oct. 31, was 127,282, and the average attendance for October, 117,734, or...

Prof. John Fiske delivered the fourth in his series of lectures on "America's Place in History," in the Brooklyn Academy of Art, last evening, before an audience as large or larger than was present on previous occasions. The three previous lectures were necessary to clear the way for that unobstructed survey of the growth and constitution of...

Trinity Church was filled yesterday afternoon with representatives of New-York's oldest families. assembled to pay the last tribute of respect to the late John Church Crage," whose funeral services were solemnized at 2 o'clock. The Hon. John Jay was among the monrners.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 19. Monday night's disaster, while not as serious as at first reported, is one of the worst that has over occurred on this lake. The loss of life, which was at first reported at 31 persons, is now found to be only six.

The Grand Jury continued its investigation yesterday into the violations of law charged against Mr. Henry J. Dudley, Superintendent of the Department of Buildings, by a committee of tax-payers of the City. A large number of architects, contractors...

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19. Not a word of testimony was taken in the Hayden trial to-day, but counsel consumed the time in arguments. The court-room was crowded, for it was plain to all that the great legal struggle of the case was in progress.

The second representation of "Aida" at the Academy of Music, last night, was an improvement on the performance of last week. The opera was smoothly given, and it may be truly said that it was a triumph for the artists and a genuine pleasure to the audience.

The trial of Capt. Alexander S. Williams, of teh Twenty-ninth Precinct, for assault and battery, in having, as alleged clubbed Charles W. Smith, of Brooklyn, at Madison-square on Oct. 15, was continued before Judge Gildersleeve, in the General Sessions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. The demonstration to-day in connection with the unveiling of Ward's equestrian statue of Gen. Thomas was, in all respects, the most imposing witnessed in Washington since the grand review of the victorious Union armies in 1865. The procession was fully two miles in length, and most of it was composed of uniformed troops.

Loud calls being made for Gen. Sherman, that gentleman stepped to the front of the platform and made a short speech a "bummer speech," as he termed it in which he thanked the Army of the Cumberland for having done a noble work, and having done it well. He eulogized the character and worth of Gen. Thomas, whoso reputation was not ephemeral, but was firm as rock.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday unanimously relieved from further duty dr. William W. Strew, the Medical Superintendent of the New-York City Lunatic Asyium, on Blackwell's Island, and his assistant, Dr. R. J. Kingston.

Dr. William Wood, of South Windsor, (East Windsor Hill.) the distinguished ornithologist, has just added to his remarkable collection-the finest, by all odds, of any private collection in this country -two large birds very seldom seen in Connecticut, and one of them believed to be an absolute stranger here.

The third day of the Seventh Regiment Fair drew forth fully as many visitors as the preceding, two days. The great armory which the regiment has erected in Lexington and Park avenues was well filled with friends of the Seventh within half an hour after the opening of the doors at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the crowd steadily increased from that time untill 10 o'clock in the evening, when the doors were closed.

Dr. Henry F. Quackenbos, one of the oldest surviving members of the Academy of Medicine, and a physician of distinguished attainments and success in City practice, lies dangerously ill in his residence, No. 39 West Eighteenth-street.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--A dispatch from Rome says: "The Italian Chambers have been prorogued to the 27th inst. In the meantime the Cabinet will be reconstructed, Signor Cairoli retaining the Premiership and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Signor Depretis taking the portfolio of Minister of the Interior, and Signor Magliani that of Minister of Finance."

BREMEN, Nov. 19 In consequence of recent developments, the Directors of the North German Lloyd's Steam-ship Company have decided to refuse transportation on their vessels to the class of heavy French silks, which are so weighted with chemicals and oils as to cause danger of spontsneons combustion.

In his heart, almost everybody thinks that he could write a book; and we are sure every woman does. Let no one persuade himself that he is an exception to the rule, or the hour of temptation may come upon him when least expected. We hesitate to describe the life of the man who has listened to the voice of the demon of book-writing.

The National Association of Trotting-horse Breeders met last evening in annual session in the Everett House. Out of a total membership of about 125, reprsenting all parts of the United States, only about 30 persons wee present. The President of the associations Mr. H. W. T. Maii, of...
George Perrine, charged with being concerned in a series of burglaries in Union County, was yesterday arraigned in the Oyer and Terminer, and entered a plea of not guilty.
At about 9:30 o'clock on Tuesday evening, Henrietta Schmidt aged about 45 years, was received at the Bellevne Hospital, from an ambalance from the Seventeeth. Precinet Police Station.

At 8 o'clock yesterday morning a crowd had gathered on the Cunard pier to see the departure of friends in the steam-ship Gallia. Mr. Thomas Bayley Potter, the distinguished free trade member of Parliament, arrived shortly after 8 o'clock, and at once proceeded to the saloon.

The Church of the Redeemer, the only Universaliat Church in Newark, N. J., is without a Pastor, and the reasons for it have created a great deal of comment outside as well as inside the Universalist circles of that city. The connection of the Rev. Dr. Jonathan E. Forrester with the church was severed on the 1st of October last.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 19. Gov. Garcelon sat with the Council to-day, both in the forenoon and afternoon session. The Hon. Andrew Lacy, of Wiscasset, who called at the Council Chamber in the forenoon to see the returns from Lincoln County, stated that he had been promised by the Governor that he might see them.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 19. In the Senate sub-committee investigation to-day Bernard Williams was recalled, and testified that "Jim" Lewis paid his way to Washington, and while in Washington Gov. Kellogg gave him all the money he wanted; Kellogg instructed the witness to offer Murray $5,000 to go to Canada and not testify.

Mr. R.A. Proctor prefaced the last lecture of his course, delivered last evening in the presence of one of the largest and most cultivated audiences that ever graced a lecture-room in this City, with a few graceful words of thanks to the public and to the press for the hearty welcome extended to him on this, his third, visit to the United States.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 20. The trial of Dr. S.R. Osmun, of the First Baptist Church of this town, for immoral and imprudent conduct, was resumed before the Special Committee of Nine this morning.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 20. Society in Syracuse showed much interest this morning in the marriage, in this city, of William Van Anden, of the Brooklyn Eagle, and Miss M. Jennie Seager, of Albany.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 20. In the Hayden trial this morning the court decided that the testimony of the late Mrs. Studley, given in Madison, except her opinions as to the girl's condition, could be received from the reporter, Mr. Root, whom the State had put on the stand for that purpose Tuesday.

Following is the response of Col. Robert G. Ingersoll at the dinner of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee, in Chicago, on Thursday last, in response to the toast: "The Volunteer Soldiers of the Union Army, whose valor and patriotism saved to the world a 'Government of the people, by the people, and for the people.'"
NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 20. The trial of Esther Mudge, who is charged with infanticide, committed at New-Berlin last Spring, will come on at an early day.

LONDON, Nov. 20. The speeches for which Michael Davitt and James Bryce Killen were arrested in Dublin, and James Daly, editor of the Connaught Telegraph, in Castlebar, were made at a meeting on the 2d inst. at Gurteen, County Sligo.

It is well to have a candid foreigner assume now and then the friendly office of pointing out the perils that lie in our way as a nation, and pry gently into the weak places of our armor, just to show that we are not invulnerable.
Two additional witnesses were examined orally in the Merrill will case, yesterday, before Surrogate Calvin, on behalf of the proponent of the will, Cardinal McCloskey.

The trial of Capt. Alexander S. Williams, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, for assault and battery, in having clubbed Charles W. Smith, of Brooklyn, on the occasion of the review of the National Guard by Gov. Robinson, was continued, before Judge Gildersleeve, in General Sessions, yesterday, and resulted in the acquittal of the accused officer.
It is satisfactory to note that the Administration proposes to anticipate the roughand-ready methods adopted by the Democrats to curtail the expenditures of the Government.
"The coldest day of the season, thus far," was a perfectly proper remark yesterday. The thermometer settled this point very satisfactorily when it dropped down to 22 at 9 o'clock last evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. Union Hall was crowded this evening on the occasion of the meeting announced by Coll Dean, a prominent stock operator, for the purpose of telling the public the location of three new bonanzas, which he claims exist on the Comstock, and of denouncing the management of the mines controlled by J. C. Flood and his partners.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 20. There was concluded in the Monroe Court of Sessions yesterday the trial of one of the most cold-blooded criminals ever known or heard of in the annals of criminal history in Western New-York.

John Derwin, one of the crew of the schooner Lawson, loaded with stone, and lying at the site of the new Barge Office, at the Battery, while on deck at 7 o'clock yesterday morning noticed a dark object floating in the water near the schooner.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 20. Much excitement was caused this afternoon by the appearance of a body of United States troops from Fort Porter, under the command of a Sergeant, on the grounds lately improved, for the purpose of building coal-chutes, by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, at the foot of Erie-street.

Rudolphe and Garnier were the contestants in yesterday afternoon's game in the Collender tournament, and they got along very well together, considering the ease with which a French billiard-player "loses his head." They were not satisfied with the one referee, who might decide for both of them, but each must have an umpire besides.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. The annual report of the Hon. E.A. Hayt, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, shows that during the past year there has been among the Indians a steady advance in civilization, which has had no parallel in any previous year. In this the Ogalalla and Brule Sioux have taken the lead, and their progress during the last 18 months has been marvelous.
The Grand Jury yesterday resumed its investigation into the maladministration of the Department of Buildings by its Superintendent, Mr. Henry J. Dudley.

The American Institute of Architects resumed its session yesterday morning, in the Directors' room of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. There were present about the same number of members as appeared at the first sitting of the convention.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 20. The Hon. Austin Harris, Senator-elect from Washington County, went to the State-house this morning under a conditional promise from Councillor Foster that he might see the returns from his own county. On reaching the State-house, however, he was informed by Mr. Foster that the Council had decided otherwise, and he could not be permitted to see them.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 20. Several marine disasters, due to the present storm, are reported. The schooner Dominion, Capt. O'Hagan, which left here, light, for Millpoint yesterday, ran into South Bay in a snowstorm and cast anchor.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 20. When the jury went out in the Jackson murder trial last evening, a ballot was immediately had, which stood 11 for guilty and 1 for not guilty. Subsequent ballots stood equally divided for murder in the first and second degrees.

Yesterday was one of the most noteworthy days in the history of the Stock Exchange. The recorded transactions reached the unparalleled figure of 683,120 shares, while the actual dealings must have exceeded 750,000 shares, the operators being clearly unable to jot them down as fast as made.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 20. J.T. Allyn, Manager of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was subpoenaed to produce all the telegrams sent by Kellogg in May or June last. He declined to produce the telegrams under the sweeping specifications of the subpoena, but said he might produce messages clearly and specifically called for, say by, and to whom sent, on what date and to what point.
A few days since we had occasion to comment on the extraordinary volume of transactions in Wall-street, which rose in a single day to over 620,000 shares.
The will of the late Rev. Dr. Joseph Parrish Thompson, formerly Pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle, who died in Berlin in September, was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate Calvin.

The large public hydraulic elevator in the north-west cupola of the Post Office Building, corner of Broadway and Mail-street, gave way shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and six persons who were being carried in the car at the time had what they believe to be a narrow escape from death, or at least serious bodily injury.

The case of John Sheridan, keeper of a liquor saloon at No. 413 East Thirteenth-street, who has attained unenviable criminal notoriety as the receiver of thousands of dollars' worth of property stolen from the residences of wealthy citizens during the past Summer, was before the General Sessions Court again yesterday.

Miss Sybil Eager, daughter of Joseph Eager, of No. 82 Summit-avenue, Jersey City Heights, was awakened at 3 o'clock yesterday morning by unusual noises in her room. Looking through an open door into a bedroom occupied by her brother Elliott and his wife, she saw a tall stranger, with a dark...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. The reunion of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland terminated to-night in a grand ball and promenade concert at the Capitol.
The next lecture in the course which is being given at Association Hall will take place this evening, when Dr. John H. Vincent will discuss "That Boy."

The Board of County Canvassers met again yesterday afternoon to receive the report of the Committee on Corrected Returns. Supervisor Perley, Chairman of the committee, presented a report based on figures supplied during their sessions, from which the board canvassed the returns omitted by the Inspectors of Election in several districts.

The Dock Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, agreed to lease the new pier, about to be built on the site of old Pier No. 44 North River, to the Inman Steam-ship Company, for 10 years, at an annual rental of $30,000. Old Pier No. 44 formerly belonged to the Inman Line, and was purchased by the City last Summer for $250,000.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 20. The Board of Commissioners of the State Survey met here to-day to take action regarding the International Park, at Niagara Falls, in accordance with the concurrent resolution of the last Legislature. Horatio Seymour presided.
Now is the time when we recall with sadness the vanished Summer days at Coney Island. It is a mistake to suppose that Coney Island is dearest in the dog-days.

The second ward of the Wetmore Pavilion of the Woman's Hospital, Fourth-avenue and Fortyninth-street, was profusely adorned with cut flowers yesterday afternoon. Strings of verdant smilax were suspended from the chandeliers and over the pictures along the walls, giving the place a cheerful appearance on its twenty-fourth anniversary.

The Seventeenth District Republican Association have had some exciting meetings during the last six months, but none of them were so animated in the beginning or so troublesome in the end as that of last night.

Some time ago the editors of the Art Interchange, a paper devoted to art news, which had its origin in the Society of Decorative Art, offered six prizes, ranging in value from $50 to $10, for the best original designs for door-curtains, painted tiles or plates, and holiday cards--the entries for competition to be placed on public exhibition at the Kurtz Gallery pending the award of prizes.

It cannot be too often repeated that the Republican victory in this State has been due to circumstances which are not at all likely to be permanent.
