An assignment for the benefit of creditors, by Abraham Lager to Max Moses, with $1,850 preferences, was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

"Il Trovatore" is not likely to forfeit its popularity if the audience of last evening at the Academy of Music is to be taken as a measure of success. The cast included Mme. Adini as Leonora, Mme. Lablache Azucena, Signor Aramburo as Manrico, and Signor Galassi as Il Conte di Luna.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 21.--Frank Merillo, otherwise Barilli, was before Judge Ludlow this morning on a requisition from the Governor of NewJersey and a warrant of extradition from Gov. Hoyt. He was charged with murder in Jersey City in killing a school boy by hitting him with a stone during a disturbance between a number of schoolboys ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The Hon. J.A. Bentley, Commissioner of Pensions, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior, shows that on the 30th of June last there were 242,755 persons receiving pensions from the Government. The pension list is now larger than at any previous time.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 21.--The fifth day's proceedings in the trial of Dr.S.R. Osmun, who is charged with immoral and imprudent conduct, began in the Methodist Episcopal Church this morning. It had been announced that Dr. Osmun would be placed on the stand, and so he was, but too late in the day to give any important evidence.

The steam-ships Germanic, of the White Star Line; the Main, of the North German Lloyd; the Ethiopia and Utopia, of the Anchor Line; the Rhynland, of the Red Star Line, and the W.A. Scholten, of the Rotterdam Line, are advertised to sail for Europe to-day.

Peter Goelet died yesterday, at his residence, at Broadway and Nineteenth-street, after a lingering illness. Mr. Goelet never fully recovered from the attack of sickness which prostrated him about a year ago.
The second meeting of the creditors of the broken Stuyvesant Bank, which failed Oct. 12, 1871, was held yesterday before Register Dwight, and about 60 creditors and lawyers were in attendance.

Business among the stock brokers in "the Street" was active yesterday. With some of the brokers it was very good and with others it was very bad, but it was lively with all of them. The "Street" was said to be excited, but only to those who mingled with the men about stock telegraph tapes, or among the swarms of yelling buyers and sellers in the Stock Exchange, ...

The tug-boat Sadie Ellis, Capt. Daniel Androvett, left the White Star Line Pier, No. 52 North River, at about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, bound for Long Dock, Jersey City. When about two-thirds of the distance across the river, she collided with the ferry-boat Secaucus, which was on her way from Hoboken to her Barelay-street slip.

During the late political campaign the Democratic Committee of Fifteen took measures to bring into existence a Democratic organization in this City independent of either the Tammany or the Irving Hail Democracy. It appointed 10 men in each Assembly district, who were to act as a general committee and organize in such a way as to them seemed proper on a permanent basis.

Platt, Assignee, and others, came up on appeal from the Circuit Court for the Southern District of NewYork. This was a suit bronght by the Assignee in Bankruptcy of Simeon Leland Co. to set aside, on account of alleged irregularities in ...
The old suit Receiver Edward M. Tompkins, of the New-Rochelle Savings Bank, against the Trustees of the bank, to recover about $20,000, was again before Referee Freling H. Smith yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--What is known as the 80 per cent. clause of the Specie Resumption act provides that whenever and as often as additional circulating notes are issued to national banks it shall be the duty of the Secretary of the Treasury to redeem the legaltender notes of the United States to the amount of 80 per cent. of the sum of national bank notes so issued.

The Nyman inquest at Passaic, N.J., was finished yesterday afternoon. Dr. J.C. Herriek, of Passaic, who made the autopsy, testified as to the result of his examination, illustrating his remarks by reference to a part of the old man's skull, which he had preserved, and which showed all the wounds found.

Very late in the day, the English Government has begun to arrest men in Ireland for using language in public speeches and newspapers calculated to incite a breach of the peace, If anything is likely to produce a breach of the peace, it is the discontent and excitement among the people.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 20.--In the Supreme Court to-day, an opinion was delivered in the case of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad against the People ex rel. Attorney-General, in error from the El Paso County Court. This case grew out of the action of Attorney-General Wright, taken at the time the Rio Grande property was wrested from the control of the Santa Fe Company.

Owing to the north-westerly gales which continued through yesterday, there were few arrivals at this port. The sailing vessels have probably been driven off the coast by the storm. The officers of the vessels which have reached port since Thursday evening say that they experienced extremely cold and stormy weather. Early yesterday the steamship Chalmette, from New-Orleans, was observed ...

Fifteen of the charitable hospitals of this City have united in an appeal for collections toward the support of their work, to be taken on the 27th and 28th of December. These two days are to be known, from year to year, as "Hospital Saturday" and "Hospital Sunday." On the Saturday indicated, boxes will be placed in prominent business places, ...

LONDON, Nov. 21.--The British steamer Borussia, Capt. Williams, sailed from Liverpool to-day for New-Orleans, with 65 farmers and their families, bound to Texas. They are mostly from Lancashire, Yorkshire, and Durham, with a few from Scotland and Ireland.

Mr. Isaac O. Hunt, Superintendent of Scows in the Street-cleaning Bureau, was brought before the Board of Police yesterday for a hearing in his defense against a charge of incompetency preferred against him by Commissioner MacLean. Mr. Hunt is an old gentleman of rather high temper, and was on his mettle during the entire examination, ...
A vessel is reported in distress off Sea Girt. Her sails are described as all blown away, and she is sagging to the south-east.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Pay Department are announced: Major G.L. Febiger is relieved from duty in the Department of the East, and will report in person to the commanding General of the Department of Dakota for duty as Chief Paymaster of that department, relieving Lieut. Col. Samuel woods, Deputy Paymaster-General.
The American Institute Exhibition will remain open to-day until 10 P.M.

PARIS, Nov. 21.--The new French cable was formally opened yesterday by a telegram from M. Grevy, President of the Frence Republic, to the President of the United States, expressing the most cordial sentiments.

The Committee of Pilots and the sub-committees of the Chamber of Commerce, Maritime Association, Ship-owners' Association, and Produce Exchange, appointed to confer with them for the purpose of securing a reduction of pilotage fees, met in the rooms of the Chamber yesterday afternoon. Mr. Gustav Schwab was chosen Chairman, and Mr. Allston Wilson Secretary.

Robinson, in answer to their request to be permitted to argue the case on the testimony taken before the Referee, George Ticknor Cnrtis:

The Town of Lynn, Mass., is one of the most quiet and old-fashioned of New-England towns. It has a fine sea-beach, and thirty years ago was quite a popular seaside resort; but for some reason Boston decided that Lynn was not fashionable, and, accordingly, its beach was promptly deserted. WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The United States Auditor of Railroad Accounts has received a communication from the Vice-President of the Central Pacific Railroad Company inclosing a check for $609,080.69, which, in connection with the amounts due the company and withheld by the United States Treasury for Government transportation, both on its subsidized and unsubsidized roads, between ...

The violence of the gale which came upon the City on Wednesday had somewhat abated last night. From a velocity of 40 miles an hour, its greatest speed, it had died away, at 7 o'clock last evening, to 11 miles an hour, with no perceptible weight. The cold was somewhat diminished, too, and there is a promise of a milder temperature today; but this chance, it is said, will be limited to a few degrees.
The wife of Eugene Amanton, French working man, left him in 1877, in Paris, and went traveling as a nurse in the family of Mr. Henry B. Livingston, of No. 17 West Washington-square, this City.

The motion made on behalf of Leo C. Dessar for an injunction to restrain the Board of Canvassers permanently from counting the votes cast in the recent election for J.C. Julius Langbein, the Republican candidate for the Civil Justiceship of the Seventh Judicial District, was denied by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 21.--Nothing has been made public yet concerning the action of the court on the reported application of counsel for the Republicans in the matter of the election returns. It is understood that counsel are completing their papers and consulting as to the time of notice.
The majority for Gov. Smith, of Wisconsin, is over 25,000, and is the largest ever given any candidate in that State.
Nearly 200 members of the Army of the Cumberland called on Gen. Sherman, at his office, in the War Department, to-day.

DUBLIN, Nov. 21.--At the meeting tonight to denounce the arrests of Daly, Davitt, and Killen, about 5,000 persons were present. Edmund Dwyer Gray, Liberal Home Rule member of Parliament for Tipperary, presided.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 21.--Directly opposite the house of the Rev. Mr. Hayden, in Rockland, is that of Luzarne Stevens, and in the Hayden trial to-day Mrs. Stevens was testifying nearly all the forenoon. She saw Mary Stannard come down to Hayden's house three times on the day before she was murdered, and twice in the forenoon of the fatal Tuesday.

The annual report of the Treasurer of the United States is an unusually interesting document, covering as it does the operations of the Treasury during" a year characterized by great transactions connected with the refunding of the war loans into 4 per cents., and the resumption of specie payments after a suspension of seventeen years." The portions of the report to which ...

YOKOHAMA, Nov. 1.--The latest returns of cholera show that upward of 90,000 deaths have occurred. The epidemic is expected to cease entirely by the end of the present year. Extraordinary precautionary measures for the future are being applied to the minutest districts. It is now believed that the Japanese sanitary system is unsurpassed in the whole world.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 17.--When the legally elected Republican Governor of Louisiana was overthrown, and Nicholls, the Democrat, by the aid of shot guns, installed in his place, there was great rejoicing in New-Orleans.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--The steamer Norfolk, from Richmond, Va., was in collision, at 7:30 this morning, off Cherry Island Flats, with the schooner N.H. Barrow, of New-York, bound out. The steamer was struck well aft in the starboard quarter, and lost her mizzen mast and smoke-stack. The schooner lost her jibloom, bowsprit, martingale, No damage was done to the hull of either vessel.

A poem by Longfellov, which will be found elsewhere in full in this paper, is the chief attraction for the month. LONG BRANCH, Nov. 22. The steamer Relief, of the Coast Wrecking Company, last night came to the assistance of the schooner Mary Chilton, which stranded inside of Sandy Hook late yesterday afternoon. This morning early the steamer got aground, and had to wait until 10 o'clock before she could float off.

Recent news from South Carolina exemplifies a new phase of the decline of sentimentalism as an element in Southern politics. WADE HAMPTON no longer wields undisputed sway in the Democratic councils of his State. He is no more idolized as its redeemer, with none to call in question the propriety of the worship.

The first special meeting of the West Side Association was held last evening in the association's new rooms, No. 64 West Thirty-fourthstreet. Dwight H. Olmstead presided, and, after stating the objects of the society, he said the subjects to be considered at the meeting were the shanties of the West Side, and the means to be adopted for their removal.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22. The Yale and Harvard Freshmen played the first of their series of foot-ball games in this city to-day, and it resulted in a victory for Yale by the score of two touchdowns to nothing.

Columbia College sent its team of 15 foot-ball players to St. George's Cricket Club Grounds, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon, to meet the team of Yale College. The two teams met, and, in addition, Columbia met with a very decided, although not entirely unexpected, defeat.

The first week of the Seventh Regiment New Armory Fair closed last evening in a manner highly satisfactory to the projectors. The day was called " Brooklyn Day," in honor of the poople who reside in the sister city.

Two more suits have been begun against the much-enjoined Brooklyn Elevated Railway Company. They are brought by Attorney-General Schoonmaker in behalf of a number of real estate owners along the line of the railway, and will be tried in the Supreme Court, Second Department. The papers were served on President Bruff, of the railway company, on Thursday.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 22. The sixth day's proceedings in the trial of Dr. S.R. Osmun attracted more people than any previous day, the crowd having been drawn by the knowledge that Dr. Osmun was to tell the whole story of his troubles with Pastor Bowman.

LONDON, Nov. Frequent Cabinet councils in London and much going to and fro of Ambassadors and messengers between European Courts give rise to all kinds of rumors unfavorable to peace. Constantinople is once more the centre of intrigue and anxiety. The British fleet has been ordered to Turkish waters.

Nothing is more characteristic at the present moment in France than what will henceforth be called the "Philippart legend." This astonishing man has found means to surprise the expectations of the wildest imagination. A day will come when it will be hard to believe that his history does not belong to the world of novels.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 20.--When Gen. Garfield, some years ago, remained in the House at the personal request of President Hayes, and refrained from disputing the Senatorial vacancy with Mr. Stanley Matthews, the universal Ohio sentiment was that the seat of Senator Thurman should be given him when the course of events had restored to the Ohio Republicans their natural majority in the Legislature.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 20. Some boys who were roaming the Ramapo Mountains, east of the Augusta Iron Works, near the Rockland County line, on Sunday last, found in a recess in the rocks two rust-eaten gun barrels, with the romnants of flint-locks lying near them.

MADRID, Nov. 22. A rupture is imminent between Premier Campos and a majority of the Conservatives in the Cortes, who have joined the planter Deputies in an attempt to retard the abolition of slavery, and obstruct the free-trade policy of the Cabinet.

Rudolphe and Heiser are having a very close contest in the billiard tournament to see who shall lose the most games. Rudolphe so far has won one game, (he won that from Heiser,) and Heiser has not won any. Rudolphe lost another game yesterday afternoon, when he played with Daly.

The conclusion of the long-protracted Nyman inquest at Passaic, N. J., was a relief to the citizens of that place, to whom the investigation was becoming a bore. The general opinion justifies the majority of the jury in holding the wife of the deceased man's son as an accessory to her husband's dreadful crime. Only seven of the twelve jurors signed the verdict against both Komah Nyman and his wife.

The week just ended has been one of the most notable in the history of the Stock Exchange. The recorded transactions aggregated nearly 3,500,000 shares, of a par value of $350,000,000, an average of about 570,000 shares per day. The real transactions were doubtless very much more numerous, as, at times, the operators were utterly unable to record the dealings as fast as made.

A very few general observations must TIVES A very few general observations must conclude this brief survey of Winter quarters. In searching for a Winter health-resort, what do we desire to avoid and what do we desire to find? There are three things which we desire to avoid, especially when they are found combined together, as in our own Winter climate, and these three things are damp, cold, and variability.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 24.--The session of the Dauphin County Court for the trial of certain members of the Legislature, and others, charged with bribery, , in connection with the Pittsburg Riots Damages bill, opened here at 10 o'clock this morning.

The Board of Police Justices met in the Jefferson Market Court room last evening, Justice Murray presiding. All of the members of the board were present, including Jacob M. Patterson, Jr., who took the seat of the late Justice Kasmire. The report of Col. George W. Cregier, Secretary of the Board of Police Justices, for the year ending Oct. 31, 1879 was read.

Mr. JAY GOULD, having shorn his lambs in Wall-street, has betaken himself to the far West. His newspaper, after having publicly prostituted itself to his uses, is as dumb as an oyster concerning the "great financial transaction" which it employed to hammer down Erie and other speculative stocks.

Mr. R.A. Proctor delivered the second and last lecture of his supplementary series in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The subject was "The Great Pyramid; its Purpose and Meaning." He began by observing that the topic he was about to treat was one of considerable difficulty, as well as one which had elicited bitter and savage controversies among the learned.

Three more cases of poisoning from eating meringue pie were brought to light yesterday. The victims were Stephen Mulvey, his wife, and their 5-year-old son, who live on the top floor of the fivestory tenement-house, No. 304 West Thirty-eighthstreet. On Monday, the 17th inst., Dr. James F. O'Reilly, of West Forty-second-street, was called to attend Mulvey, who was reported to be in a dying condition.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 24.--This morning there are about 400 convicts on the sick list. A few have been restored to duty, but others have taken their places, and the disease is practically unabated.

Controller KNOX'S report blends the evidence of great financial achievements with the proofs of impending mischief. If on one hand it seems to justify national exultation, it tends on the other to awaken anxiety and to demonstrate the need of remedial legislation.

Heiser had his last chance yesterday afternoon to win a game in the Collender tournament, and failed, so he will be able to go home to Boston with as clean a record of nothings as any billiard-player could have.

The Mosel, from Bremen, brought 272 immigrants and $1,300,000 gold yesterday. Eighty-four proposals have already been received for the 40 seats offered for sale by the NewYork Stock Exchange. A transfer seat was sold on Saturday for $15,000.

At the session of the Grand Jury yesterday, the charges against Superintendent Dudley, of the Building Department, were taken up and occupied several hours.

A plain hearse, bearing the body of the late Peter Goelet, was driven up to the entrance of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church at 10 A.M. yesterday, followed by less than half a dozen carriages. In one of the coaches were the chief mourners, Messrs. Ogden and Robert Goelet, and Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry, nephews of the dead bachelor, and Frederick Gallatin, his nephew-in-law.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 24.--The steamer Circassia, of the Anchor Line, Capt. Munroe, from Glasgow Nov. 13 for New-York, with the American mail, arrived at this port this morning at 10 o'clock, having in tow, disabled, the Inman steamer City of Richmond, Capt. Leitch, which left Liverpool Nov. 13 and Queenstown Nov. 14 for New-York, with the American mail.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 24.--The Colt party to-night in honor of the twenty-first birthday of Caldwell H. Colt, only son and child of the late Col. Samuel Colt, was attended by all the prominent society people of Hartford, and many from abroad.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 24.--Manager Alleyn, of the Western Union Telegraph office of this city, was called before the committee to produce certain telegrams, in accordance with a memorandum furnished him Thursday.

Armstrong, on Jan. 23, 1878, was taken up this morning. Graham was brought from the Camden County Jail by Sheriff Calhoun.

NEW-HAVEN, NOV. 24.--The evidence in the Hayden trial to-day was neither very interesting nor very important. In fact, it has been one of the dullest days since the trial began.

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury, mentions the improved condition of the service; first, in regard to the receipts; second, in respect to the character and efficiency of the officers employed; third, in respect to the disposition of tax-payers to observe the laws; and fourth, in regard to public opinion in reference to the enforcement of the laws.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 26. Mr. Gladstone, on receiving a Liberal address here, made a long speech. MADRID, Nov. 29. The marriage of King Alfonso to the Austrian Archduchess Maria Christina was solemnized thin forenoon. The great game of Saturday night, which resulted in a victory for William Sexton, brought the Collender tournament brilliantly to a close. Sexton previously held the Delaney championship medal, and now the emblem of "Champion of Champions" lies beside it, testifying to the player's great prowess with the cue.

Messrs. Gilbert and Sullivan begin their season of "Pinafore" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre this evening. They have brought over a number of the leading artists of the company, and the preparations have been made under the supervision of the two authors of the work. Mr. Sullivan is to conduct the performances, the report to the contrary being expressly denied.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov.26. Owing to the absence of Judge Bond, who is expected here to-morrow, no business has as yet been transacted in the United States Circuit Court. A motion will be made on his arrival to set aside the juries drawn for this term on the ground that the Democratic Jury Commissioner, Col. Trenholm, was not legally appointed.

SCRANTON, Penn.,Nov.30. The miners of this region are jubilant over the announcement made by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western and Delaware and Hudson Canal Companies that they have advanced the wages of their men 10 per cent., to take effect to-morrow. More welcome news has not been received ...

The Republican Government and Republican France appear determined to open up commarcial relations on an extensive scale with Central Africa. It is proposed among other schemes to run a railway from Algeria to the Soudan, and now the Republique Francaise announces that MM.Zweifel and Moustier, representing the house of Verminck at Marseilles, have reached the sources of the Niger.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov.30: The rural districts of New-Jersey are as thoroughly agitated on the Sunday question, to be discussed during the ensuing session of the Legislature, as are the large cities; and it is in these country portions of the State that the strength of the Sabbath Party lies, just as the anti-Sabbatarians cluster around Newark and Jersey City.

AMITE, La., Nov.27. The political cam paign now rapidly drawing to a close in Louisiana has been, in many respects, the most remarkable the State has known since the war. Particularly remarkable because during its progress no Republican, white or black, has, for his opinion's sake, been killed or beaten.

Quite a ripple of local excitement has been occasioned here in the past few days by the awakening, through American enter, prise, of the interest in the development and working of the Chaudiere district gold mines, and there is at present some likelihood that the paying productiveness of these mines will be tested in a scientific as well as a business-like manner.

The committee having in charge the arrangements for the funeral of the Rev. Dr. William Ives Budington, late Pastor of the Clinton-Avenue Congregational Church, met yesterday afternoon for the purpose of giving final form to the details for that ceremonial.

The audience on Saturday afternoon at Mr. Sherwood's piano recital was somewhat equal to the merits of the occasion, and more than twice the size of the audiences at each of the two previous performances.

LONDON, Nov.30. The meeting in Hyde Park to-day, in response to the call for an organized demoustration in favor of the Irish agitators, consisted of an immense mob. A fair sprinkling of green favors was observable, but by far the greater number of the persons present seemed to be attracted more by curiosity than by sympathy.

The Paris Figaro and Vienna Tagblatt publish simultaneously, and by agreement between the two journals, a conversation with King Alfonso touching the causes which led him to ask for the hand of tho Archduchess Christine, after having most sincerely thought he should wear perpetual mourning for his first wife.

ALBANY, Nov.30. Governor-elect Cornell has devoted a good deal of time, since the election, to the composition of the staff of officers who will assist him personally in the administration of his office, and it is likely that within a week he will have decided upon most of the persons who are to be appointed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. The hotel corridors are crowded tonight with Senators and Representatives, fully a quorum of the members of both houses being now in the city. That part of the President's Message which relates to the currency fulfills the highest expectations of his friends.

ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., Dec. 1. James Meags, age 19 years, and William Walton, age 23, were out hunting hares today, when, by the accidental discharge of Walton's gun, Meags received the full charge of shot in his groin, inflicting a mortal wound. Meags was brought to his home at Jamesburg, and is not expected to survive the night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. The usual crowds which attend the opening of Congress filled the galleries and corridors of the Capitol to-day. The House was the principal attraction, and every seat in the galleries was filled one hour before the speaker summoned the members to answer roll-call.

Gen.Jefferson C. Davis died at the Palmer House, Chicago, on Sunday afternoon, after being confined to his bed for five days with pneumonia. Week before last the General attended the reunion of the Army of the Cumberland, in Washington, and took a severe cold at the unveiling of the Thomas monument. He reached Chicago on Tuesday of last week, intending to remain there during the Winter.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 1. A dispatch to the Denver Tribune says that the White River Utes came into Los Pinos last Saturday, and went before the commission. A new plan of examining the witnesses has been adopted, and several are allowed to enter the Commissioners' room at once. They all wear arms, though concealed.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 1. The eighth week of the Hayden trial was begun at 2 o'clock this afternoon, Judges, jurors, lawyers, and the accused man appearing promptly in their accustomed places, all giving evidence of the refreshing effect of their Thanksgiving vacation. The court-room was crowded, as usual a large proportion of the spectators being ladies.

Last night the annual dinner of the St. Andrew's Society was hold at Delmonico's, and some hundred and fifty gentlemen attended on the festive occasion. The preparatory meeting was held on the 13th ult., at which the officers of the year were elected. The President then elected, Mr. John S. Kennedy, presided at the dinner, seated at the place of honor at the cross-table which stretched across the room at the north end.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. The Democratic Party held its conventions to-day, to nominate candidates for ward officers and to choose delegates to attend the conventions which meet tomorrow, and which in turn elect delegates to the State Convention.

LEBANON, Penn., Dec. 2. Henry Wise, one of the murderes of Joseph Raber, was sentenced this morning to be hanged. He attempted to deliver a written statement, but was stopped by Judge Henderson. Drews and Stichler were hanged recently for the crime. The sentence of Wise was deferred in order that he might testify against Zechman, alleged to be another of the gang.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. The Democratic Senators held a caucus this morning, during which a number of matters were informally discussed, but nothing definite was decided upon. It is usual, at the beginning of a session, for the respective parties in the Senate to meet in caucus and make such changes as may be desired in the standing committees.

The lecture delivered by Prof. Macloskie last Monday evening on "Flies" ought to have been warmly appreciated in fly circles. There are few animals of which less is generally known than is known of flies. The lecturer corrected so many popular mistakes in regard to flies, and gave so much information as to their habits and customs, that he deserves to rank among our very ablest fly experts.

TORONTO, Dec. 2. Col. Grey and Mr. Bald, the delegates of the Great Western Railway of Canada sent to America, have returned home. They state that their visit has been very successful taken all around. The arrangement with the Wabash line, although not what could have been desired, is fairly satisfactory. Improved traffic returns are anticipated. Their report will be issued to the Great Western proprietors in a few days.

MANCHESTER, Dec. 2. The market is quieter, and in most department the demand is slow. India and China merchants continue to buy piece goods very sparingly, but there is a fair inquiry for yarns for china at Friday's rates. For other foreign markets, and for the home trade, the business is small, or at best, moderate, the full prices required checking sales greatly.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 2. As soon as the Governor and Council met this morning, the Senators and Representatives from the various counties, accompanied by their attorneys, went to the State-house in full expectation that they would be allowed to examine the returns in their several cases.

The twentieth anniversary of the execution of John Brown, of Ossawattomie, was commemorated with exercises of an interesting character yesterday afternoon and evening in the Shiloh Presbyterian (colored) Church, in West Twenty-sixth-street, of which the Rev. Henry Highland Garnett is the Pastor.

Mr. JAY GOULD, one of the money kings of Wall-street, and the principal proprietor of the New-York Tribune, is recuperating his wasted energies by a trip in the far West. Nobody can deny to Mr. GOULD the possession of remarkable abilities.

Last July a new art publication was begun in London under the editorship of H. M. Cundall, of the South Kensington Museum. It is a separate monthly to supply the increasing demand for the etched work of artists. J. W. Bouton is the agent for the United States.

Moscow, Dec. 3. For the fourth time the Czar of Russia has escaped death from assassination. The first attempt on his life was made in April, 1866, at the gate of his Summer garden at St. Petersburg. The wouldbe assassin was a student named Karakasoff, and his weapon was a pistol.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 3. Twenty-four hours have elapsed since the closing of the polls throughout the State, and as yet things are badly mixed. It would seem that the Republicans stand a chance of victory should the vote be correctly counted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--Mr. James A. Dumont, Supervising Inspector-General of Steam Vessels, in his annual report, shows that during the last fiscal year there were 4,289 steamers inspected and 15,212 officers licensed. The total number of lives lost by accidents from various causes aggregated 177. 44 of which are not chargeable to accidents resulting from the use of steam in navigation.

An audience of perhaps 2,000 persons assembled at Steinway Hall last evening to listen to an address by Mr. Wendell Phillips, entitled "The Press--Its Power for Good and for Evil." A decision which once more places upon a bank the responsibility for paying money upon forged checks was rendered yesterday by the General Term of the Superior Court. The suit was one brought by the firm of Frank Hirsch against the Chemical National Bank.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 4.--Thanksgiving week broke up the monotony of life at Harvard very agreeably to most of the students. A recess of 46 hours was allowed by the authorities for the purpose of disposing of the conventional turkey, but many students, living within 300 miles of Cambridge, managed to secure the greater part of the week away from college.

The second International Dairy Fair was opened in the American Institute Building last evening. The doors were opened to the public at 6 o'clock, and by 8 about 500 persons had gathered in the great hall. The preparations for the fair were in an incomplete condition, and the knowledge of this fact probably deferred many who would otherwise have been present from attending the opening.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 8. The report of the hanging of three Republicans in Madison, just prior to the election, proves, on thorough investigation, to be untrue. Ouly one was killed. The two others are still alive, though one was shockingly outraged. The man, Armstrong, who was killed, was President of a Republican club, and was a resolute fellow, who talked back.

"I do wish, mother, that that old poke of a Chancellor would hurry up and decide my case, I'm tired of staying in Newark just on his account, and want to get back home to Montreal." Such was the remark made a few weeks ago in a railroad station in Neward, N.J., by a handsome young lady to an elderly matron, evidently of Hebrew birth.
LONDON, Dec. 8. The ship Springfield, Capt. Peart, from Jarvis Island for Hamsburg, put into Bremerhaven, being cut through with ice. She also lost her anchors, chains, and hawsers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. The recent outbreak of the Ute Indians in Colorado has brought prominently before Congress the question whether they shall continue to be located in that State, and several bills have already been introduced looking to their removal from the Colorado reservation to the Indian Territory, or elsewhere.

The new armory of the Seventh Regiment was littered with rubbish yesterday, and a gang of workmen was at work removing the gaudy booths. Many of the booths, being of unique form, were bought or raffled off for use as green-houses and arbors at the country seats of members. The booth belonging to Company D was drawn by ex-Sergt.
"La Carmavgo" is to be produced on Thursday evening by Mr. Gran's company with a cast including the principal artists.

Catherine Cull, of No. 67 Monroe-street, appeared before Justice Duffy, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, as complainant against her husband, August Cull, whom she charged with a variety of crimes. Cull is an organist in a prominent church and a music teacher. His wife said that she had been married to Cull for 27 years, and had had 11 children, of whom five were now living.
BOSTON, Dec. 8. Judge Powers, of Vermont, has rendered a decision against the Lamoille Valley Railroad, which secures to the laborers on that road $8,000 of wages overdue.
The body of Thomas F. McPhillimy, aged 16, who fell off the dock at the foot of Gold-street, on Saturday night, was found yesterday within a few yards of the place where he was drowned.

In response to the call of the Central Committee, primary elections for the selection of delegates to the next Republican Central Committee and for officers of the district associations will be held to-night. In most of the districts caucuses were held last evening. The indications, so far as known, are that in all the districts except three or four the primary elections will be quiet and uueventful.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 8. H.C. Hartwell, counsel for Francis E. Hayden, opened for the defense today. He claimed that the arsenic found in the body either came there by the administration of bismuth by Dr. Jewett, or by the suicide of the deceased girl, arising from her many troubles. The prisoner was called to the stand.
It is announced that Dr. P.E. Doulin, of No. 1 Ludlow-place, will be Coroner Knox's deputy.
The Greenbackers of West Virginia are to hold a meeting for conference in Parkersburg on the 6th of January.

The English freight steam-ship Monarch, which arrived here yesterday, broke three blades of her propeller in midocean and was obliged to put into Halifax for repairs. Capt. Dobson reports sailing from Liverpool in ballast on Nov. 9. Severe head gales began as soon as the vessel was in the Atlantic.

The body of a boy, apparently about 15 years of age, was brought to the surface of the river yesterday at the Pavonia Ferry, Jersey City, by a muddigger used in excavating at that point. It had been in the water for some time. There was nothing about the clothing by which deceased could be identified.

The thirty-ninth annual reception of the Brooklyn Art Association took place last night. It is reported from Washington that a bill would have been submitted to the House yesterday by its Committee on the Electoral Count, had the presentation not been prevented, by the early adjournment. The Chairman of this committee is Mr. GEORGE A. BICKNELL, of Indiana.
ST. NAZAIRE, Dec. 8. Viscount Lesseps, the promoter of the Panama Ship Canal scheme, has sailed for Aspinwall. He is accompanied by his wife, three children, and 15 other persons.

Among the passengers by the steam-ship Bahama, from Trinidad, which arrived yesterday, were eight escaped prisoners from the French penal colony of Cayenne, New-Guiana. They are strong, dark-visaged men, who look as though they had passed through much rough usage. They were dressed in all sorts of garments, evidently picked up here and there in their travels.

Mr. McDONALD, of Indiana, presented a memorial of John H. McLane and another, relative to the taking of illegal fees in the United States Clerk's office in the Circuit Court for the Southern District of Ohio. Referred to the Committee on Judiciary.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 8.--The trial of George Price, colored, for the murder of Villie Block, the tobacco commission merchant, on May 13 last, was begun in the Court of Common Pleas to-day, before Judge Longworth.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 8. Special dispatches to the Denver Tribune from Los Pinos, dated Dec. 6, represent that Saturday witnessed some decidedly animated occurrences at the Commissioners' meeting. HAVANA, Dec. 6--The question of the abolition of slavery in this island, as it approaches solution in the Cortes at Madrid, is the absorbing topic of discussion by all parties. The insincerity of the slave-owners in their professions of desiring reform is shown in the tone of their newspaper organs on the subject of abolition.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 10.--Louisville, for about two months, has been expecting Gen. Grant, who arrived to-day. The skies clouded up yesterday, and a steady pour has been kept up over since. At 1 o'clock yesterday the rain ceased, and the reception took place before it could come down again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--The annual meeting of the National Board of Trade began here to-day. Very little business was transacted at the opening session beyond organization and the reading of the report of the Executive Council. Frederick Fraley, of Philadelphia, was unanimously re-elected President, and now begins his twelfth year in that office.
John Carroll, of No. 240 Mulberry-street, was found drunk at No. 33 Spring-street yesterday. He died a few minutes after his arrival at the Mulberry-Street Police Station.

At a meeting of the Cabinet, on Tuesday, it was ordered that the terms of surrender, as agreed to by Chief OURAY, of the friendly Utes, should be accepted.

On Monday last, the Clinton Hall Association purchased of James D. Fish a plot of ground on the south-east corner of Broadway and Thirty-seventhstreet, payiag for it $180,000. The plot has a frontage of 106 feet on Broadway and of 136 feet on Thirty-seventh-street, and covers nearly five City lots.

The trial of ex-County Collector Hart Moore, for embezzlement, was continued yesterday in NewBrunswick, N.J., before Judge Scudder. T. Stewart Brown continued his testimony as to the results of his investigation of the county accounts.

The Rev. Enoch Cobb Wines, D.D., of Irvington-on-Hudson, the Secretary of the National Prison Association, died suddenly at Cambridge, Mass., yesterday, in the seventy-fourth year of his age. Dr. Wines was born in Hanover, N.J., Feb. 17, 1806. He was educated at Middlebury College, from which institution he was graduated in 1827, at the age of 21.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10--The Hayden furors, as they filed into the court-room at 9 o'clock this morning, showed no evidonce of physical ill resulting from their Rockland excursion yesterday. Judges, counsel, court officers, and reporters were all promptly in their places, none appearing any the worse for their picnic in the wilderness.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 10.--About one year ago an exposure was made of the pitiful condition of the Dutchess County Almshouse, in the Town of Washington, and the attention of the State Board of Charities was called to the matter. Though statements have been made that the situation there had been exaggerated, recent developments prove that half had not been told. Crowded into the miserable tinder-box are 136 inmates, breathing sickening odors in ill-ventilated

HONESDALE, Penn., Dec. 9.--At the December Term of the Wayne County Courts for 1878 Erastus B. Hollister, Justice of the Peace; George Burns, a brother of Hollister's wife; William A. Meyers, a young carpenter, and Fannie Van Gorder, daughter of a well-to-do farmer, were indicted on charges of conspiracy, arson, burglary and robbery.

Some days ago Inspector Murray received from a source, which he declines as yet to divulge, information that a serious case of malpractice and infanticide took place in July last, and that a woman doctress of this City, who has figured in several similar cases, was implicated.

On arriving at his home, at No. 102 East One Hundred and Twenty-first-street, at 4 A.M. on the morning of Sept. 17, Officer Charles Dooloy, of the Eighteenth Precinct, met a milkman named James Warren, who lived only two doors away, in the act of leaving Mrs. Dooley's bedroom, and, drawing his revolver, Dooley shot Warren in the breast.

Yesterday was the most interesting day thus far in the trial of the indicted officers of the Mechanics' and Laborers' Savings Bank, Jersey City. The prosecution had up to yesterday morning devoted their attention to efforts to prove that the bank was insolvent in May. 1877--a year and a half before it closed--and that during that 18 months the defendants knew it to be insolvent.

There is no part of the human frame which is more unsatisfactory than the liver. No boy ever had any fun with his liver, and no man ever found his liver a source of pleasure or a means of improvement.

The New-England Society held a special meeting in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last evening, Judge Noah P. Davis presiding, and a large number of members being present. After the election of 29 new members, a committee was appointed to nominate a board of officers for the ensuing year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--The Coroner held an inquest, this morning, in the case of Bernard Riley, who was shot and killed during a political riot in the Fifth Ward, on Dec. 2. After hearing the testimony, the jury returned a verdict that Riley came to his death at the hands of John McManus, and that Thomas Ryan was accessory before the fact. McManus has not yet been arrested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8.--Several days ago Secretary Sherman made an important contribution to the financial history of the past two years, in the correspondence and documents concerning the resumption and the refunding of the national debt, which he transmitted to Congress, or rather to the House of Representatives.

In September, 1873, a produce-dealer named John L. Randall, doing business in Boston, and living at Melrose, near that city, procured insurance against fire on his stock in trade, consisting of oils, drugs, and painters' materials, contained in a brick and slated building situated at No. 41 Central Wharf, Boston, to the amount of $62,500, to 21 different insurance companies, all of which corporations were foreign to the State of Massachusetts.

Trainor and four seamen who had abandoned the bark in another boat were supposed to have been lost.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 10.--The Common Council, by a vote of 9 to 5, has adopted the Vanderbilt plan, with a few modifications, for elevated tracks from the east limit of the city to the high grade commencing near the centre of the city and going west.

MR. WEAVER, of Iowa, presented a petition, signed, as he stated, by 20,000 persons, asking for the passage of an act granting to soldiers and sailors the difference between the value of the money with which they were paid and gold, with 6 per cent additional.
The Treasury Department to-day purchased 260,000 ounces of silver for the Philadelphia Mint. Secretary Schurz does not expect any further news from the Ute Commission until Friday or Saturday.

There was an unsually large batch of prisoners arraigned to plead to indictments in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, before Judge Benedict. George Williams, James Burns, James A. Clark, Hugh Currie, and Matthew Rooney, indicted for having in their possession and passing counterfeit money, pleaded not guilty.

Many persons assembled in the Anthon Memorial Church at 8 o'clock last evening, to see a marriage ceremony which has been a topic in good society for two or three weeks. The groom, Mr. Charles Salisbury Fitch, has been well known for a long time in New-York society.

BERLIN, Dec. 10.--Intelligence from St. Petersburg says: "Another number of the new revolutionary journal, entitled The Will of the People, has been distributed in St. Petersburg, and other parts of Russia. A party--consisting of Mayor Cooper, Controller Kelly, and Chamberlain Tappan, Commissioners of the Sinking Fund; Dock Commissioners Vanderpoel and Dimoek, and Assistant Engineers Nichols and Kidd, of the Dock Department--yesterday afternoon went from the foot of Chambers-street in the tug Manhattan to examine the premises of the New-York Central Railroad on the river front between Sixty-first and Sixty-fifth streets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--The Senate, in executive session this afternoon, unanimously, and without reference to a committee, confirmed the nomination of ex-Senator Ramsey to be Secretary of War.

PLANO, Ill., Dec. 11.--James Longacre was shot and killed yesterday by C.M. Bennett. Longacre had been engaged to Bennett's sister, but the engagement had been broken. Yesterday he went to Bennett's house with the avowed intention of marrying the girl anyway, but he was ejected. He then threatened to kill Bennett, whereupon the latter shot him through the head, and the Coroner's jury justified the act.

CARRICK-ON-SHANNON, Dec. 11.--The session of the Connaught Winter Assizes opened today. During the day several processions of Irishmen paraded the streets, and all approaches to the court-house were thronged with people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11.--The National Board of Trade met at 10 o'clock this morning. Various unimportant amendments to the constitution were adopted. The Fulton, Municipal, and Williamsburg Gas-light Companies, of Brooklyn, voted yesterday in favor of the scheme, which has been under consideration for some time, to consolidate all the gas companies in one great company, which it is proposed shall have a monopoly of the business of furnishing gas to the City of Brooklyn.

MILFORD, Penn., Dec. 15. The present term of Pike County Court, which convened here to-day, promises to be the most exciting and interesting session that has been held for years.

The seventy-fourth annual meeting of the New-England Society was held in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last evening. Mr. George H. Moore was chosen Moderator of the meeting. President Daniel F. Appleton presented his annual report, in which he mentioned the names of 20 members who had...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. There are very few members of the Republican National Committee in the city this evening, except those from the West, most of whom are in favor of holding the convention in Chicago.
An executive session of the Board of Police was held yesterday, all the Commissioners being present and Commissioner French occupying the chair.

NEWTON, N.J., Dec. 15. At this place tomorrow will be commenced the trial, in which much interest is taken, of a tramp named Johnson. A short time ago he stopped at the house of George Rubert, who lives in Sandyston Township, Sussex ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15. There has been much controversy in the Town of Derby for some time over Post Office affairs. Originally them were two Post Offices in the town, one in Birmingham and the other in Ansonia, Derby proper being without an office.

Mlle. Marimon made her third appearance in New-York last night before an audience that was notable alike for its numbers and its character. Many of the most prominent persons in New-York society were either conspicuous in the boxes or mingled with the multitude in the stalls.

Yesterday, before Justice Bixby, Sergt. Keating, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, charged John Dermody, who was attired as a woman, with intoxication in the Madison-Square Garden. Dermody is a lemon-peddler, who, to use his own expression, "lives all over." He believes that he is a pedes-...

The great East River bridge, which has been 10 years in growing to its present dimensions, was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening, in the Brooklyn Music Hall, by Mr. Edmund F. Farrington, Master Mechanic, who has been connected with the present undertaking ever since the project to unite New-York and Brooklyn by one mighty span took practical shape.

The trial of the indicted officers and Directors of the defunct Mechanics' and Laborers' Savings Bank was resumed before Judge Garretson, in Jersey City, yesterday. Receiver Williams, called for the defense at the close of Mr. Collins's argument, testified that, speaking generally, he thought that the mortgage securities held by the bank were at the time they were taken worth their face value, and more, in most cases.

The case of the foundling who died on Friday last while in the charge of Ann McGuinness, at No. 301 East Forty-sixth-street, has revealed a new use to which policemen are put by the managers of charitable institutions to which they are detailed by the Board of Police.

Yesterday was the sixth and closing day of the trial of Joseph and Mary Volkmar, indicted for having attempted to administer poison, with murderous intent, to Charles E. Blair, of Chatham Village, N.Y., in their apartments, at No. 114 Essexstreet, on Thanksgiving Eve.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. Brevet Major-Gen. A. McD. McCook, in charge of education in the Army, has submitted to Secretary Ramsey a report on the post schools for the month of October, 1879.

A number of gentlemen assembled last evening in the rooms of the American Geographical Society, at No. 11 West Twenty-ninth-street, to discuss the question of the proposed Nicaragua Ship-canal from Graytown on the Atlantic coast to Brito Harbor on the Pacific coast, ...

Representative Hutchins introduced in the House to-day a bill to amend certain sections of the Revised Statutes relative to banks and banking. The effect of the proposed amendments will be to remove the 10 per cent, tax on the circulation of State banks, and to allow national banks to deposit with state banks whose capital is at loast $400,000, and whose surplus capital is equal to 25 per centum in addition.

Dr. CROSBY has written to the papers to say that when he prosecutes a liquor-seller in the New-York courts, the Judge inquires whether the witness tasted the liquor, and if he did not, refuses to sustain the complaint. This is a rule which is only to be understood and justified upon the principle of evolution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--No business of public importance was transacted in either house to-day. The session of the Senate was about an hour in duration, which time was mainly occupied in the introduction and reference of bills. Mr. Voorhees introduced a peti- ...

Mr. Robert Lenox Kennedy was yesterday elected a Director of tho Farmers' Loan and Trust Company.

LONDON, Dec. 15. The Viceroy of India telegraphs to-day that Gen. Roberts reports that his force is now collected in the Shirpur cantoument. The loss on the British side in the fighting yesterday was 19 men killed, including two officers, and 88 wounded, including three officers.

The reduction of the entrance fee from 50 to 25 cents had the anticipated effect upon the attendance at the Dairy Fair, which yesterday began the second and last week of its existence for this season.
ALBANY, Dec. 15.--It is announced that Governor-elect Cornell has made the following selections for his military staff:...

LONG BRANCH, Dec. 15. The schooner Artie Garwood, which came ashore here yesterday morning, Was completely broken up by the surf on the next high tide, at 8 o'clock last night, and the fragments of the vessel are strewn along the beach for a mile. The cargo of coal is in the breakers, completely out of sight, and will be a total lose.

There has been much excitement in the rubber trade all over the world, and particularly in this country, for several days. The excitement was brought about entirely by the manipulations of a certain Spanish house in the trade.

The Presbyterian Synod of Long Island assembled last evening at Jamaica, and began the task of reviewing the case of the Rev. Dr. Talmage, in compliance with the appeal of the dissenting members of the Brooklyn Presbytery, and in the manner recommended by the Judicial Committee of the Synod.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. Mr. Samford's bill, introduced in the House today, regulating the manner of counting the votes for President and VicePresident of the United States, provides that the two houses shall assemble in the Hall of the House of Representatives at noon on the second Wednesday ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. Nearly 150 more colored emigrants from North Carolina reached this city to-day on their way to Indiana. This party had made arrangements with the railroad companies to be taken to their destination, and remained here only a few hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16.--If a demonstration so overwhelming as to be wearisome be a success, to-day's reception to Gen. Grant certainly fills the bill. Nothing ever seen in New-York City can compare with it in immensity, and on few occasions since the outbreak of the war has a similar amount of enthusiasm been manifested anywhere in this country. The annual report of the New-York central and Hudson River Railrond Company for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, which has just been completed by General Auditor T.P. Chambers, contains a mass of figures which will interest many persons who have read the reports of the Railroad Committee's investigation of railroad management.

A large number of paintings by John La Farge were sold in Boston last year, and on Thursday and Friday next, at 3 o'clock, there will be another sale at Leonard's Gallery, Boston. The collection now on exhibition comprises all the available pieces remaining in the studio of La Farge.

Dr. William H. White, of No. 307 Fifthavenue, who made an assignment last March to W. C.A. Fuller, has filed schedules showing total liabilities $108,171 41 of which there are contingent $544,466 56; the assets are nominally $81,153, the real value being $10,800.

The Texas and Pacific Railroad Company having authorized the issue of new mortage bonds, for the purpose of extending the road from Fort Worth west to El Paso, on the Rio Grande, a distance of 640 miles, the building of the extension will be begun as soon as the company to construct it has organized, which will be in about two weeks.

In response to a call issued by Judge Hilton, F.W. Stevens, J.W. Gerard, Lispenard Stewart, and others, somo 25 property-owners on Broadway met in Parlor No. 101 in the Metropolitan Hotel, at 4 O'Clock yesterday aftornoon. The call was for "owners interested in lots on Broadway, and desirous of having property owners control any railroad which may be built on that street."

The Prall steam-heating scheme, which has been before the Aldermen for the past month, occupied the attention of the board yesterday for nearly an hour, during which every amendment calculated to result in obtaining a large remuneration for the franchise was voted down.

The bill that Judge BUCKNER,of Missouri, has introduced in the House of Representatives, to amend the law in relation to the registration of vessels, seems to be sub stantially the same as that which Senator BECK presented to the Senate in the opening days of the session.

A brilliant reception was given last evening at the residence of the Hon. Marshall O. Roberts, No. 107 Fifth-avenue, by Mrs. Marshall O. Roberts and her sister, Miss Endicott, of the famous NewEngland family of that name.

Thirty-two years ago, Elisha Ruchman, now a ruddy faced and not prepossessing looking man of 66 years, was a young and enterprising wholesale dealer in oysters, doing a flourishing business, which has since enabled him to retire to an estate at Tappan, in Rockland County, with a fortune estimated at $500,000.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 16. The indignation over the intended action of the Governor and Council in counting out enough Republicans in the two branches of the Legislature to give the State to the Democrats and Greenbackers is intense.

In his conversation with Gen. HAWLEY, the President tersely stated one fact and two opinions connected with the position of the currency question in Congress. The fact is so suggestive that it may well take the place of much argument.
The Synod of Long Island reassembled at 8:30 A.M. yesterday at Jamaica to review the case of the Rev. Dr. Talmage, as presented in the appeal of the minority of the Brooklyn Presbytery.

Capt. Christien Pedersen, of the Norwegian bark Plimsall, which arrived from Copenhagen yesterday, reports rescusing the crew of a sinking Italian bark on Nov. 9, in latitude 37 55' and longitude 23 23'.

Detectives Golden and Dusenbury, of the Central Office, arrived in this City last evening, from Washington, D.C., having in their custody Robert May, alias James Townley, a young Englishman, who is charged with having attempted to defraud Mrs. Catharine M. Jones, of No. 707 Fifth-avenue, by forging her name to a check for $1,600 on the Bank of America.

There is a general impression at Washington that the soldiers in our frontier forts spend their spare time in gambling. Naturally, the Congressional mind is filled with horror at the thought that sinful games should be played by men in the service of the United States, and bills have been in troduced by virtuous legislators to put a stop to the practice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. The Army Retiring Board having found Capt. John H.Coster, Eighth Cavalry, incapacitated for active service, he is, by direction of the Secretary of War, in consequence thereof, granted leave of absence until further orders.

Forty-three new cases of measles were reported to the Board of Health yesterday. Mr. H.E. Sharpe will lecture this evening in Room No. 24, Coopor Union, on "The Condition, Present and Prospective, of the Working Classes." Admission free.

The attendance at the International Dairy Fair last night was very good. The Hon. J.T. Updegraff, Congressman from the Eighteenth Ohio District, delivered an address on dairy Products as they should be viewed by Congressmen.

A very select assemblage of guests saw a marriage ceremony performed by the Rev. Father Daly yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock which has been a topic in society for the last five or six weeks. The bride was the only daughter of Mr. W.B. Shattuek, a retired banker, of No. 574 Fifth-avenue.

The city to-night continues to present an unwonted holiday appearance. The streets are crowded with people, and calcium lights are stationed everywhere, for the purpose of bringing into relief the more beautiful of the decorations. Thus far the Police have arrested 27 thieves. A few robberies have been reported, but none of such a character as might have been expected in the general excitement.

LONDON, Dec. 16. The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade for the past week, says: "Great distress has prevailed in the agricultural districts owing to the severity of the weather, which is now, however, somewhat ameliorated. Farm work has been almost at a standstill. Root crops have suffered severely from intense frost.

Mr. Bartely Campbell's play, "The Vigilantes," was advertised for production in Albany on Monday night, but it wss not played there. The reason why was hastily but graphically told last night by Mr.William Dinkelspiel, a manager of traveling theatrical companies.

The ex-President's party slept last night on board the special train, which started from Harrisburg at 6 o'clock this morning. The car which it occupied was Mr. Pullman's private carriage. The Jewish Feast of Chanucka, or Feast of Dedication, was celebrated by the Young Men's Hebrew Association in the Academy of Music, last evening. The feast continues eight days, and yesterday was the closing day.

The will of Peter Tostevan, the wealthy onilder, who committed suicide on Dec. 8, at his residence, No. 82 South Tenth-street, has been offered for probate in the Surrogate's Office. The estate is valued at $100,000, and the will, after providing for certain bequests, devises the property to his widow and eight children.

Lawrence Bowe, a junk-dealer, doing business at Watts and Greenwich streets, was put on trial in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, on charge of receiving stolen goods. The prisoner was jointly indicted with Henry Muller-who keeps a liquor saloon over Bowe's store Patrick Farrell, Martin McNally, and Bernard Fallon.

Edward Ryan, aged 38, a carpenter, living at No. 171 Mulberry-street, was shot through the right breast and dangerously wounded by a stranger, with whom he had a slight quarrel, in front of No. 90 Greene-street, last evening, and the assailant succeeded in making his escape.

Patrolman John Curran, of the Twenty-second Precinct, had a desperate encounter with a maniac at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and is now a patient in the Roosevelt Hospital in consequence. The lunatic with whom he camp in conflict is John Curry, a, carpenter, 35 years of age, living at No. 402 West Sixty-third-street.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 16. William Harralson, a storekeeper at McBean, a station on the Central Railroad, 15 miles from this place, was found dead in his store to-day. His head had been out open with a hatchet. Anderson Jones, a colored man, who was to accompany him to Augusta this morning, has been arrested for the murder.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Mr. Muller, of New-York, will to-morrow introduce in the House an important bill relating to the port of New-York. It is entitled, "A bill for creating a permanently deep, wide, and straight channel through the Sandy Hook Bar of the port of New-York, for the purpose of forming an improved commercial outlet."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16. The Hayden trial entered upon its tenth week today. Speculation concerning the probable further duration of the trial generally limits it to three weeks. It is still expected that the defense will complete the presentation of its case this week, although the length of time the witnesses were kept on the stand today tends somewhat to weaken the belief.

The project of constructing a horse railroad along Broadway occupied much of the attention of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. It was introduced in a communication from Mr. John B. Haskin, repeating the offer he made in March last to purchase the franchise for himself and his associates, so build a road along that thoroughfare from Centra1 Park to the Battery.

Public interest in tho women's walk, in the Madison-Square Garden, increased yesterday. There were a great many ladies among the spectators, and they filled the boxes on both sides of the building. The only pedestrian who retired during the day was Maggie E. Smith, who left the track soon after midnight with a score of 60 miles.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 16. Gen. Roberts telegraphs from Kabul that one mountain gun was lost during Sunday's engagement. Gen. Roberts estimates the number of the enemy at 30,000 men. Their fire, he says, was severe. He is confident of his ability to restore the British authority in Afghanistan, but says reinforcements are necessary to enable him to act vigorously.

Mr.KING, of Louisiana, offered a resolution for the appointment of a select committee of eleven, whose duty it shall be to examine into the subject of the selection of a suitable route for an interoceanic ship canal, to which all petitions, memorials, and reports relative to such canal shall be referred, and which shall have authority to report at any time, Adopted.
The second concert, of the season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night was an improvement on the public rehearsal of the day before, and was in itself a highly satisfactory performance.

At the trial of the indicted officers of the Mechanics' and Laborers' Bank, in Jersey City, yesterday morning, Henry Carroll, Formerly a Director, continued his testimony for the defendants. ExJudge William T. Hoffman, of counsel for the prosecution, cross-examined him.
In the election which was held in the State of Maine in September last, the Republican candidates for Governor and the other State offices received a plurality of 19,000.

Mr.BRUCE, of Mississippi, introduced a bill to provide for the investment of certain unclaimed pay and bounty money, now in the Treasury of the United States, and to facilitate and encourage the education of the colored race in the several States and Territories. Referred to the Committee on Education and Labor.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 17. The Pacific Mail steam-ship Clyde, which put into Hampton Roads disabled, will be towed to Norfolk and put in the Government dry-dock at the Navy-yard for repairs.

Miss Ada Cavendish is now on her way to New-Orleans. "Divorce" was played yesterday afternoon at Daly's Theatre. "Our Girls" was produced at the Boston Museum on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. Commissary-Sergt. Eugene Smith has been ordered from Fort Independence, Massachusetts, to report for duty to the commanding officer at Fort Preble, Maine, relieving Sergt. Gilman C.Hall, who is ordered to proceed to Fort Lyon, Colorado, and report for duty.

Between 40 and 50 gentlemen met in Parlor F of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, last evening, in response to circular invitation issued "to Irish-American citizens and friends of Ireland," for the purpose of considering the best means of giving a reception to Charles Stewart Parnell, M. P., President of the Irish National Land League, and of " enabling him to lay his views on the Irish land question before the American people."

An extremely complicated divorce case is that in which Mrs. Phebe Robertson, her former husband, W. R. Robertson, and her present husband, Richard C. Fellows, are the principal figures. Mr. and Mrs. Robertson drifted apart about 10 years ago, and for some years Mrs. Robertson heard and and saw nothing of her husband.

I have no hesitation in stating that the House of Detention in St. Petersburg, where Mirsky and the other political prisoners were confined, has been built on the latest models of prison construction, and is administered with a noticeable regard for the health and humano treatment of the prisonors. It is used for political offenders, but is also used for ordinary criminals. It will hold 900 prisoners.

The ninth annual report of the Department of Docks, for the year ending April 30, 1879, has just been submitted to Mayor Cooper by Commissioners Dimock and Vanderpoel. The report is dated Aug. 6, 1879, and contains no explanation why it has taken five months for it to come from Duane-street to the City Hall. The business of the department is reported to be constantly increasing.

Mr. Epes Sargent is recovering from his illness. He is at his home in Boston. A handsome granite monument, sarcophagusshaped, and standing six feet high, is to be placed this week over the grave of the late Dr. Edmund R. Peaslee, at Hanover, N.H.

Mr. John H. Sherwood and Mr. Benjamin Hart, gentlemen of wealth and dispositions to liberally patronize the fine arts, have for several years been collecting examples of the work of the best artists in Europe and at home. Mr. Hart's taste led him to purchase for his collection only foreign works, and in selecting them he procured specimens which have since become valuable by the death of the artists who painted them.
LONDON, Dec. 17.--The Viceroy of India telegraphs to-day that communications with Gen. Roberts are interrupted. The interruption is near Jangdalak.

LONDON, Dec. 17. It is stated that arrangements have been concluded for the completion of the new National Opera-house on the Thames Embankment,the construction of which was suspended some years ago. Work will be resumed soon.

The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $323,753 72, and from Customs $417,161 85. The Treasury Department to-day purchased 318,000 ounces of silver bullion for the United States Mint at Philadelphia.

The Teachers' Association will give a Christmas reception at Steinway Hall on Saturday evening. The number of volumes in the Mercantile Library amount to 186,000; the periodicals in the reading-rooms, upward of 400.

The strange character of the charges and of the testimony in the suit of Mrs. Margaret Ruckman for a limited divorce from Elisha Ruckman caused the court-room of tha Supreme Court, Special Term, to be crowded yesterday. At the opening of the court, Mrs. Ruckman was recalled to the witnessstand. Her cross-examination was finished without eliciting anything new.

The trial of William Kelley for complicity in the robbery of the Manhattan Savings Institution is still in progress in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. The only witness examined yesterday was Patrick Shevlin, the man who was employed to watch the banking-room on Sundays, and who entered into conspiracy with the robbers.

NEW-GLASGOW, Nova Scotia, Dec.19. Mrs. Stewart,89 years old, has been drowned in Lochaber Lake, Antigonich County. It is believed that, while in a state of somnambulism, she left her room early in the morning, and went down to the lake, where she was found drowned in two feet of water. The deceased woman was the mother of the Rev. Donald Stewart.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23. At a meeting of the Corporation of Dublin, yesterday, the Lord Mayor announced the receipt of a telegram from the Mayor of Adelaide, Australia, inquiring whether Ireland would warrant an appeal to be made there for relief for the destitute Irish, and that he had replied that great distress was anticipated in the South and West of Ireland, and that public aid was most desirable.

A dispatch from Blue Rapids, Kan., 100 miles west of Atchison, states that the Buell woolen mills at that place were burned at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The fire originated in the upper story of the building. It was a fine stone structure, and supplied with the latest and best machinery, which was destroyed.

Perry, the colored man who has direct charge of the refugees going from North Carolina to Indiana, has returned from the West, and is now here waiting the arrival of another party from the South. Perry and another colored man named Taylor Evans are the general superintendents of the exodus from North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. The United States Consul at Valparaiso, in writing to the Department of State under date of Nov. 3, reports the wreck and total loss of bark Midas, of Bath, Me., Andrew Curtis, master. She went ashore about 40 miles south of Valparaiso. None of her crew was lost. The rescued men have been provided for by the Consul.

Two men were robbed of their money and their watches, in the sleeping car, one night last week, between New-York and Providence. These robberies are becoming so frequent as to seriously affect the security of traveling at night. People cannot travel without money or watches, and if these are not reasonably secure against theft, night travel will become restricted.

The work of street-cleaning proceeded yesterday, and to-day another effort will be made thoroughly to clean the down-town streets. The work done yesterday was mainly of a character to help the mild weather get rid of the snow.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. About six years ago the National Bank at Wellsboro, Tioga County, in this State, was broken into and robbed by some of the most skillful burglars in the country.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 24. Advices from St. Louis report that city ice-bound, with the Mississippi River thence to Cairo unnavigable because of ice. Here, almost in the same parallel, there has been no sign of ice in the Ohio River, which, for its entire length, is almost free of ice and rising rapidly.

The Government has re-leased from the Brooklyn Trust Company, for a term of four years, the building which is now occupied as a Post Office. The rent is reduced from $5,000 to $4,500 a year, and an additional floor, to meet the increased business of the office, is included in the lease.

One thing was settled as to the relation of a lawyer to his clients, by the recent action of the Hartford County Bar, that is matter for public rejoicing. The Bar permits members of it to do many queer things. It sometimes happens that men keep their names on the rolls long after it is matter of common notoriety that they are dishonest and guilty of disgracful practices.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 24. Charles G. Bosse, late book-keeper at Alexander Mitchell's bank, was arraigned in the Municipal Court this morning charged with embezzlement. He pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to two years in the House of Correction.

The Fifth Maryland Regiment, with full band and drum corps, will attend the inauguration of Gov. Hamilson on the 14th of January at Annapolis. The regiment will defray their own expenses, and while at Annapolis will be the guests of the Governor's Guards.

Dinkgrave, in Monroe County, La., near the Texas and Arkansas Line, captured an illicit still, and arrested the distiller, named Burck. Mr. Dinkgrave was fired upon and wounded.

ROME, Dec. 28. The funeral of Gen. Avezzana was a very imposing one. The Police, amid a tumultuous scene, seized an Italia Irredenta flag in the procession, but their attempt to seize a Republican flag was frustrated.

Now that the Mapleson opera company has taken its departure and will not return till March 1, a review of the work they have accomplished will be interesting as a matter of musical record, and will tend, moreover, to dispel a notion, which has prevailed to some extent, that the opera this season has not been all that was to be expected.
The body of Patrick Kinifen, a sailor, who was drowned on Saturday at Pier No. 20 East River, was recovered yesterday.

Yesterday was Hospital Sunday, an institution now too familiar to citizens of New-York City to need special description, and collections for the destitute sick were taken in most of the wealthier churches Presbyterian, Methodist, Dutch Reformed, Lutheran, and Baptist, as well as Episcopalian.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. The conference of the Republican State Committee, on Tuesday, will be attended, probably, by most of the members. The purpose of the leaders in the party is to call "an early convention," and Wednesday, Feb. 25, is very likely to be fixed on. There may, however, be same opposition to so early a day.

Mr. Sims Reeves sang recently at a ballad concert in London, and, wonderfnl to state, his performance is not praised. He gave notice in advance by deputy that he would not respond to encores. One can hardly imagine such a notice to a New-York audience.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 One o'clock A.M. About 11 0'clock last night a fire broke out in one of the chief business centres of the city, and much valuable property has been destroyed.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 28. "Sam" Woodruff and "Joe" Seminole, the latter a half-breed Indian, who murdered R.B.Hayward, a farmer of Jefferson County, on Sept. 10, were taken from the jail at Golden and lynched at 1 o'clock this morning by 150 masked men.

The Rev. Dr. Fulton preached in the Rink, Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, last evening, to a large congregation, on "Fraud in Maine and Everywhere." His text was from Proverbs, xi.: 3: "The integrity of the upright shall guide them; but the perverseness of transgressors shall destroy them."

LONDON, Dec. 29. A portion of the bridge across the Frith of Tay was blown down while a train from Edinburgh to Dundee was crossing at 7:14 o'clock last night. The gale was so strong that steam-boats were unable to reach the scene of the disaster, but several mail-bags have been washed ashore four miles from the bridge, and there is no doubt that the train is in the water.

Kelly, attracted by their suspicious actions, went up to them and asked what business they had there.

WASHINGTON, Dec.28. Gen. Grantmade his first public appearance since his arrival in this city, this morning, at the Metropopolitan Methodist Episcopal Church, where he regularly attended divine service while he occupied the White House. The announcement that he would be present had drawn together a large congregation. The pews were crowded and there were many chairs in the aisles.

The Executive Committee to prepare a reception for the Hon. Charles Stewart Parnell on his arrival here held a meeting last night in Room No. 24 of the Cooper Union. About 100 of the 300 members were present, Judge Alker, of the Marine Court, presiding. The sub-committee reported that a Reception Committee, consisting of 33 gentlemen, had been agreed upon.

AUGUSTA, Dec. 28. The Rev. H.W Tilden, Pastor of the Baptist Church, delivered a lecture this evening to a large audience upon the count by the Governor and Council. He thought that partisan utterances from the pulpit were not well, but that in great emergencies like the present it was legitimate for ministers to speak out.
