CINCINNATI, Dec. 28. Railway development in Indiana during the year 1879 has been something unprecedented in the history of that State. Several important new lines have been opened but the most noteworthy changes relate to the reorganization and consolidation of the old companies. Nearly all the travel and traffic between the West and NewYork and other Eastern seaports must pass through Indiana.

When the year opened, Kheireddin Pasha had been but a few weeks Grand Vizier. His appointment had the approval of all the foreign powers interested in the execution of the treaty of Berlin, and it was further thought that he was the only man who, by a firm and wise application of internal administrative reform, could prevent the entire disappearance of Turkey from the list of European Governments.

In the recent appeal to the Synod of Long Island of the Talmage case, the Rev. J.M. Sherwood was selected by his "fellow-complainants" to present the moral bearings of the action of the majority of the Brooklyn Presbytery in acquitting the Tabernacle's Pastor. His remarks were not only logical in the extreme, but were pervaded by a common sense which is no less but no more rare in ecclesiastical than in other assemblages.

In Italy there were two Ministerial crises; about the middle of July, Cairoli and his associates succeeded the Depretis Cabinet, and toward the end of November there was another list of appointments, including that of Signor Depretis as Minister of the Interior. The changes had little effect on the policy of the Government, and were nothing more than the results of coalitions to drive common rivals from power.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 28. A meeting of negro immigrants from North Carolina was called for last night at the Court-house in Greencastle, Ind. The purpose of the meeting was to compare experiences and interchange views as to the propriety of encouraging the movement.

On July 12, the German Reichstag, by a vote of 217 to 117, passed a law establishing a strongly protective tariff an act which is as significant politically as it is important financially. For 12 years Bismarck has been supported in his efforts to establish German unity by the National Liberals, but, in supporting the tariff bill he arrayed himself against that party's declared free-trade or revenue-tariff principles.

LONDON, Dec. 28. The Viceroy of India, under date of the 27th inst., announces that telegrams from Gen. Roberts report the defeat and dispersion of the enemy around Kabul, on the 23d inst., before the arrival of Gen. Gough.

The annual meeting of the Board of Directors and Trustees of the Mount Sinai hospital Association was held yesterday in the hospital lecture-room, over 100 members being present. Mr. Hyman Blum occupied the President's chair. The report of the board for the year ending Nov. 30, 1879, represented the administration of the affairs of the institution to be in a generally successful and gratifying condition.

AUGUSTA, Dec. 28. Numerous petitions were forwarded to Gov. Garcelon to-night, praying him to refer all matters in dispute touching the election of members of the Legislature to the Supreme Judicial Court. Bangor sends five large petitions, embracing in all 587 names, including men in all professions and callings in this city.

PARIS, Dec. 12. American enterprise has achieved another victory. The Werdermann electric light may not be an American invention, its discoverer may not be an American, but if one of our countrymen had not taken it in hand, it would have remained, so far as France is concerned, hidden under a bushel for evermore.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--About 7:30 this evening William Meehan, residing at No. 1,020 Filbert-street, threw his wife down stairs, and she died in half an hour. Meehan is from New-York, and has been here since last August. The couple have one child in New-York and twins 18 months old here. Meehan was arrested. He is a brass founder. Both he and his wife were intemperate.

In France, events of the first importance succeeded each other with startling, but always logical, rapidity. On Jan. 5 occurred the election of Senators in the 29 departments, from the Haute-Garonne to the Oise. The result was a sweeping victory for the Republicans. Before the election those departments were represented by 19 Republican and 56 Conservative Senators; after it the figures were 69 Republican and 15 Conservative.

For England, 1879 was, without qualification, an unhappy year. The depression in trade was almost unprecedented, and gave rise to excited discussions of the tariff, in which doubts as to the wisdom of unqualified free trade were influentially expressed. The farmers did so badly that a revision of land laws was vehemently urged as a necessary supplement to a nearly universal reduction of rents.

Mr. CHARLES STEWART PARNELL, Irish member of the British Parliament for the County of Meath, after spending some months in his own country in stirring up the people to sedition against the laws and authority under which they live, and to acts of injustice against owners of land and against each other, is on his way here to ask aid and sympathy in his misdirected crusade.

The Governor of Maine, placing his hand on his heart, declares that he is not only satisfied with his work, but is actually proud of it. We should not expect too much of a fifth-rate country doctor, accidentally hoisted into a Gubernatorial chair, but the self-complacency of this willing tool of the conspirators is something marvelous. He has his lesson well by heart.

RALEIGH, Dec. 27.--An impression exists at home and abroad that North Carolina, politically speaking, is in much better condition than any other Southern State. Considering the probability that the Old North State will not fall in line with the so-called solid South next year, a statement of its vote, beginning with the year 1868, and a review of the political situation, will be of interest at the present time.

The NOrwegian bark Vegar, Capt. Olsen, which arrived at Quarantine yesterday, had on board the crew of the Norwegian bark Venerate, which was abandoned on Nov. 17, in latitude 37 and longitude 14 30. Capt. Olsen reports sailing from Oporto on Nov. 11. On the seventh day out a sailing vessel, evidently in distress, was observed, and the Vegar approached her.

The Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, consisting of Mayer Cooper, Controller Kelly, Chamberlain Tappan, and Mr. Nicholas Haughton, the Chairman of the Aldermanic Committee on Finance, met yesterday for the purpose of taking appropriate action on the death of their late fellowmember, Recorder Hackett.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 29.--A party of Philadelphia and New-Jersey capitalists have commenced a survey between Sea Girt and Point Pleasant for a proposed railroad, to form a junction of the Freehold and Jamesburg Railroad with the Central Railroad of New-Jorsey at Sea Girt.
LONDON, Dec. 29.--A St. Petersburg correspondent says he knows that the first step toward a rapprochement between England and Russia has been taken in an unusual and significant manner.
